2017-12-05 15:55:44

*Thread Reply:* Member of Group and attempting to access ActiveSync? Deny Claim

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2017-12-05 15:56:49

*Thread Reply:* Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve got thus far

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2017-12-05 15:56:50

*Thread Reply:* exists([Type == ‚Äúhttp://schemas.microsoft.com/2012/01/requestcontext/claims/x-ms-client-application‚Äú, Value == ‚ÄúMicrosoft.Exchange.ActiveSync‚Äù]) && exists([Type == ‚Äúhttp://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/groupsid‚Äù, Value =~ ‚Äú^(?i)S-1-5-21-2184843080-1574357790-3623606500-225877$‚Äú]) => issue(Type = ‚Äúhttp://schemas.microsoft.com/authorization/claims/deny‚Äù, Value = ‚Äútrue‚Äù);

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2017-12-05 15:57:10

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôve tested w/ just the Group SID and that checks out

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2017-12-05 15:57:38

2017-12-20 18:55:00

Hi everyone üôÇ Does any of you know whether it's possible to sync the Archive folder (assuming you have the appropriate license for the online archive feature) through ActiveSync with Exchange 2016 ? I know this is possible with Office 365 and I assume MS use Exchange 2016. It is not possible with Exchange 2013 (which is the only on-premise environment I have as of now).

Angela (angi.szabo@gmail.com)
2018-01-04 13:59:55

*Thread Reply:* as I know ActiveSync doesn't provide support for archive mailboxes. (it is also mentioned here: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn922147(v=exchg.150).aspx ) Activesync v16 has only the new feature to sync draft folders

Amine (amine.ayad@gmail.com)
2018-01-15 15:39:31

üëç:skin_tone_2: Simon Hardy-Bistagne
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-01-30 18:28:00

*Thread Reply:* I know what we will be looking to test tomorrow...

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2018-01-30 23:12:38

*Thread Reply:* I've pushed it to the lab. Seems ok but:

* Missing controls for sync * Can't stop additional accounts being added * No DLP controls * Signature.. etc?

I'll keep an eye on it, but I'm not going to be advising orgs use it any time soon with AE.

üëç Woody
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-01-31 08:11:59

*Thread Reply:* With regard to DLP controls and additional accounts; these are more MAM policies and are covered in the Intune Graph API. Sync settings would be nice indeed. Microsoft does mention refinements and additional settings will be published in the future. You can always chime in here also: https://microsoftintune.uservoice.com/forums/291681-ideas.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-01-31 14:14:03

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, IdK how long I‚Äôve been asking Apple for the ability to update the preconfigured signature. Yet, they nor Microsoft seem to get it. At least some Android clients will allow for it.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2018-01-31 14:22:04

*Thread Reply:* Doesn't matter if they're considered MAM policies, they're still present on competing clients and used to offer a modicum of security. They're targeting on-premise exchange with this very release where Graph APIs wouldn't even come into it.

Good start nonetheless, so we'll see what they prioritise

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-01-31 14:30:00

*Thread Reply:* If I could issue one reaction to this post it would be (slow üëè)

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-01-31 14:38:46

*Thread Reply:* You could still use Intune, with Exchange on-prem. MAM policies would be still be applied if set. So, Graph API is still possible, as long as you have Intune or Intune licenses. Competing clients typically also needs some kind of MDM/MAM before this can be configured. Except for the native mail clients on Android and iOS (and limited DLP settings), you would need some kind of containerised mail client to be able to set DLP policies. These typically are not covered in the basic MDM license. Not saying this is optimal either way, but it's available for configuration and a step in the right direction. It seems Microsoft is now more focused on using generic "standards" to be able to configure it (iOS managed app config and Android AppRestrictions) instead of its own proprietary methods.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-01-31 14:44:50

*Thread Reply:* I see where they‚Äôre going with it @Mark Vonk, but they have to realize how tough it‚Äôll be trying to sell all that to a customer who just wants a secure mail client.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2018-01-31 14:48:30

*Thread Reply:* Sorry Mark, I'm thinking about this from a non-Intune perspective, which makes up the majority of the EMM customer base I've ever dealt with, some of whom have expressed interest in Outlook in the past which I've advised against due to the lackluster management capabilities and for them today it's still not viable.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-01-31 15:54:50

*Thread Reply:* @Woody It‚Äôs the same for the majority of the EMM customers. Most of them want to control and secure email access. It‚Äôs what got MDM started and still for most under-developed EMM customer the first and foremost use-case.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-01-31 15:56:36

*Thread Reply:* @Jason Bayton not viable because it will cost them more money, ie an Intune license? Or are you missing anything specific?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-01-31 16:03:23

*Thread Reply:* We deal with multiple MDM platforms and EMM customers ranging for simple and small to large and advanced. We too have had numerous talks about the lack of management and security options for Outlook. But now, Microsoft basically offers two things: basic remote management from any EMM. If you need more, you can opt to use Intune or the Graph API for a premium. I do not see this strategy as any different than other EMMs are doing. I do not see BlackBerry, MobileIron, VMware, etc giving any management options, outside of their own EMM, on their productivity apps... I just think it‚Äôs good that we have some now, which we can even use in other EMMs and happy Microsoft decided to use standards.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2018-01-31 16:14:23

*Thread Reply:* Except MI, AW and presumably BB offer their clients as EMM business email clients, not general consumer like Gmail, which does offer decent management on any AE-supported EMM platform. A lot of drive for Outlook comes from it being a popular consumer app as well, and ramping up an intune instance to configure the outlook app doesn't make a lot of sense when other clients are available. So that's how it'll stay until they add more functionality or customers find other reasons to spin up intune.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-01-30 19:58:20

ActiveSync with basic auth? Microsoft still using passwords...BlackBerry/Good had this sorted with KCD years ago! It‚Äôs not the native Outlook app but still...

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-01-30 20:00:28

On another note, we‚Äôve had to use Airwatch coupled with their IdM to achieve true SSO with regards to modern auth in O365. Microsoft just doesn‚Äôt really care about the end user experience...I don‚Äôt get that...

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-01-30 20:02:38

*Thread Reply:* Yes we're doing the same with ping. It's the only way to restrict outlook to managed devices.

This piece with provisioning an account payload into the app is the missing piece. I'm sure the API will support a pki payload as well though.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-02-07 19:18:55

Russell Mohr (rmohr@mobileiron.com)
2018-02-10 00:16:31

You do have MDM control for auto updates with device based app Assignment

Russell Mohr (rmohr@mobileiron.com)
2018-02-10 00:16:37

And VPP

Russell Mohr (rmohr@mobileiron.com)
2018-02-10 00:18:15

Check with AirWatch to see if you can shut these off. But of course, you need to have deployed device based app assignment. You can do this after the fact by converting outlook to a managed app and associating a license to it

Russell Mohr (rmohr@mobileiron.com)
2018-02-10 00:18:53

Or if already managed, just adding the license to it.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-02-10 13:32:34

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-02-10 13:34:46

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-02-10 13:35:18

So the only real way to control this is via device based app assignment/ VPP?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-04-11 08:42:14

Anyone else using Todo app under intune mam?

Ms updated the app yesterday and since then users are getting messages that it dept are blocking the app.

Just trying to see if anyone else is seeing this?

Duncan (duncan@govalux.com)
2018-04-11 10:23:14

@Simon Hardy-Bistagne What we are facing with Intune is that when using per-app-VPN on Android, it isn't 'on-demand'; our users were a kind of used to the experience that when they launched the Android app the (MobileIron Tunnel) per-app-VPN was established automatically and within a second or so. With Intune we are using Pulse Secure in the per-app-VPN mode; but unfortunately it isn't on-demand on Android (user will have to launch the VPN manually). Also, while it does do on-demand-per-VPN on iOS, it seems to take about 10 seconds or so to have the VPN established, which is making 'on-demand' a bit of a relative thing (but maybe that is caused by something in our infrastructure and not so much by Intune).

Duncan (duncan@govalux.com)
2018-04-11 10:27:21

Another topic is that Intune doesn't have a feature to locate devices, or at least it is quite limited; Intune only allows to find the location of a Supervised iOS device. Non-supervised iOS devices as well as Android devices cannot be located with Intune. Within our company we do have countries where location tracking is important as truck drivers and sales reps should be moving now and then; and location tracking is used as a (personnel) security feature. With Intune we will have to implement some 3rd party app for that.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2018-04-11 10:31:30

Android doesn't support VPN on-demand natively. Always-on is fine, but per-app requires support is built into the VPN client, or you leverage Samsung-specific APIs.

Jason (jasonh@bridgeway.co.uk)
2018-04-11 10:55:07

It‚Äôs a shame to see this move away from powerful EMM solutions and onto Intune, where in fact, the integration of the two (Graph APIs for Office app DLP) is often the best approach, IMHO. Especially as Intune is ‚Äòfree‚Äô - it just seems daft to me not to leverage the investments in the current EMM solution, with the added capabilities of Intune to boost this further?

üëç Mark Vonk, Woody, NicolasR
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-04-11 12:42:26

Pulse Secure, within Android Enterprise should be capable of Always-On I believe. When you set it up correctly, with allowed or disallowed apps, the user experience is almost the same as Per App VPN with iOS. With Always On, the VPN is always on in the background and as soon as a user starts an app that is allowed, the VPN is used. That is the same way MobileIron Tunnel for Android Enterprise actually works.

websterba (websterba@gmail.com)

üëç Woody
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-06-14 08:21:15

Indeed, there is no VPN-like technology. Intune/EMS uses/promotes the Azure Application Proxy for mobile devices to access internal resources: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/manage-apps/application-proxy

docs.microsoft.com
How to provide secure remote access to on-premises apps
Covers how to use Azure AD Application Proxy to provide secure remote access to your on-premises apps.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/manage-apps/application-proxy
üëç Woody

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-06-25 17:55:40

@Woody uploaded a file: image.png

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-06-25 18:06:56

I see the entry under the CAP for ‚ÄúApproved client app requirement‚Äù, but that only lists Microsoft‚Äôs own apps. No mention of a bundle ID for something such as the SalesForce app.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-06-25 18:08:44

Yes, if you select "approved clients" only those can access the data behind that CA rule.

You have to create a mam policy that explictly calls out the app if the data comes from another app, or you can't use the approved clients rule.

We have this issue where we want to use Microsoft's own todo app, but can't as it doesn't appear on this list.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-06-25 18:09:40

Oh, yuck LoL

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-06-25 18:10:08

Okay, let me step through that MAM bit and give it a shot

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-06-26 19:47:31

BTW, That did the trick @Simon Hardy-Bistagne. Managed Apps are now able to access the service behind AAD.

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-02 09:17:23

@Luc has joined the channel

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-02 09:18:03

hi all anybody of you have implemented an authentication by certificated on exchange ?

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-02 09:19:07

i find a doc done by james saturnion i just wahnt to know if you have any experience on this subject

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-02 09:19:21

thx üôÇ

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-02 19:19:22

@Luc Are you speaking to CBA with on-premise Exchange or O365?

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-02 20:40:39

hi eric i m talking about with on premise exchange

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-02 20:57:28

one idea is to set the sentry in pass trought but i m not so fan about this idea

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-02 21:16:26

Well, I suppose Sentry could pass-thru but if it‚Äôs CBA (or nothing), you might as well direct the client straight to the public URL of the ActiveSync array.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-02 21:17:07

Device Trust/Management is implied when it arrives with a certificate. Otherwise, denied.

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-07-02 22:46:39

Hi Eric, I don‚Äôt agree, device trust is not 100% guaranteed when a certificate is presented.

  • Depending on how the certificate is validated, I can be delivered by the internal CA but doesn‚Äôt contain the right information in it, it just means someone found a way to export the keys.
  • If the device is jailbroken/rooted and the attacker found a way to avoid certificate to be removed by the EMM, the direct access to EAS is allowed if no Sentry is involved
  • there a lot of cases where IT wants to block the device but not delete the data (minimum OS version, non connected devices,...)
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-03 02:52:09

@NicolasR Good points. 1) Typically the cert would need to contain SAN values. Are you saying that someone could export and/or modify the values within the SAN after it‚Äôs been issued? 2) Is it possible to separate/extract the embedded Exchange certificate identity from the device cert store when a device is jailbroken? 3) Certainly. In that case, a Sentry with Cert-based KCD would certainly be put to good use.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-03 02:54:02

@Luc Re-thinking my answer a little‚Ä¶ I understood that you wanted to just go straight CBA into ActiveSync. If you are on-premise, the most secure method would be to deploy Sentrys and use the cert-based, Kerberos Constrained Delegation. This would get you the password-less auth experience and all the security that Sentry delivers being tightly integrated with the MobileIron EMM.

Luc (luc.rames@digitaldimension.fr)
2018-07-03 09:06:45

@Woody and @NicolasR thanks for you answer i will tell you what my customer choice after the meeting

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-07-03 09:14:00

@Woody Modify the values of a certificate after it is issue is not possible. But as SCEP/NDES works, the template could include dummy values and issue a dummy certificate from the right CA. That's why exposing a SCEP server on the internet in a BAD idea... üôÇ SCEP protocol requires only a SCEP Challenge which is a shared secret...

About extracting a certificate, that's something that is quite easy for a knowledged person. RAM dump or Keystore flows, you can do whatever you want on a jailbroken/rooted device. Also, a CA can deploy certificates to Windows PC, these certificates could be re-used to authenticate to the EAS if there is no specific SAN info to check.

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-07-03 09:14:13

Not sure that Sentry + KCD is a more secure solution

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-07-03 09:15:31

Always keep in mind that a good certificate authentication is something complex to implement. You should always check the CRL, always check SAN values that give you more faith on the certificate

‚úÖ Woody
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-07-03 09:20:34

Just to pop in that comment from me again... we have ping doing our cert auth, which is also checking the compliance of the device presenting the cert through airwatch.

‚úÖ Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-03 15:27:29

@NicolasR Good info all around. Not having a direct background in security I‚Äôm always interested to hear more.

I would say the only real two benefits the Sentry gets you is that it first checks the cert validity to allow the incoming connection request. It then would check the SAN values (UPN/DN) and subsequently initiate the Kerberos session. There‚Äôs a good bit of spoofing to be done, but it could be defeated.

Second would be (as you mentioned) that it can block access as a result of a device falling out of compliance (while not removing the Exchange profile as a whole).

Matthew Shaver (mshaver@us.ibm.com)
2018-07-03 17:08:09

üëç Woody
jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2018-07-13 17:19:44

XenMobile also shines when it comes to MAM security. On top of standard device level encryption, XenMobile adds an additional layer of FIPS-120-compliant app-level encryption for each individual application container.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-13 17:25:51

I‚Äôm assuming that this would apply to their own set of apps and not the Microsoft suite ?

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-13 17:28:15

We also require that the passcode is changed every 90 days and after 10 tries the device is factory reset. Impossible to enforce that outside an agent...

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-13 17:34:16

The balance between BYOD and Security is a delicate one...but no passcode on the device means no file data encryption and a hacker‚Äôs paradise!

üòÜ Woody
üëç Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-13 18:26:36

I‚Äôm with @jafullersr, the only way you could deny access to apps (based on state of the overall device passcode) would be some sort of wrap/container that the app was partaking in

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-13 18:59:24

Agreed

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2018-07-13 19:03:08

It breaks Apple‚Äôs EULA to wrap 3rd party apps. This is not a good approach to MAM.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-13 19:18:17

Interesting - wasn‚Äôt aware of that but all EMM solutions have their own wrapping possibilities right and it‚Äôs been around for ages...

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-13 19:19:06

How does one get around the passcode dilemma though from a security perspective? I mean I don‚Äôt know a single person who doesn‚Äôt have a passcode set but still...

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2018-07-13 19:33:00

Yes, EMM can wrap if it‚Äôs your app. Let‚Äôs say your app devs don‚Äôt want the hassle of dealing with pesky things like enterprise encryption. Wrapping via the EMM can cover that for you. In this way the application can have encryption enabled whilst the device does not. Good application developers would not depend on device encryption to protect the application data.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-13 19:33:25

Well, I think it‚Äôs different when you as the author bake-in the control/wrap for your own app (as opposed to taking someone else‚Äôs and wrap/publish)

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-13 19:33:39

LoL. Exactly what @jafullersr said. GMTA

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2018-07-13 19:34:17

Yes and this is where Apple‚Äôs EULA protects the app store developer from this sort of engineering.

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2018-07-13 19:35:05

B2B is different still. That EULA is between the developer and the enterprise. Thus, those versions of the app can be wrapped unless the developer EULA is explicitly prohibiting it.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-13 19:35:48

Right. I like B2B. Can‚Äôt believe how many people arent‚Äôt using it‚Ä¶

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-13 19:36:04

and there‚Äôs no cost. Just education of devs/companies

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2018-07-13 19:37:25

Yup.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-07-16 13:18:48

I assume Duo is also ‚Äúaware‚Äù and can limit access based on that. But without a MDM profile, you can‚Äôt enforce anything like this. Duo mentions this in the article: https://duo.com/blog/secure-byod-without-an-mdm: ‚Äù If mobile devices do not meet security requirements, users are asked to enable specific security controls, such as a passcode, or they are blocked from accessing their work applications.‚Äù

The Duo Security Bulletin
Secure BYOD Without an MDM
Duo Beyond is a user friendly alternative to mobile device management (MDM) solutions that helps businesses secure BYOD.
Original URL: https://duo.com/blog/secure-byod-without-an-mdm
Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-16 13:33:22

Regarding the Duo statement, that‚Äôs a type of enforcement though as in they won‚Äôt be able to use their apps. It doesn‚Äôt necessarily force the use of a passcode but it‚Äôs a requirement if they want to access their Corp apps

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-16 13:34:32

It doesn‚Äôt go into detail though on how they do that exactly. What about Lookout @Simon Hardy-Bistagne? Can it block access to certain apps if a passcode is not defined?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-07-16 13:42:39

LookOut does not block anything. It does not have an enforcement agent or anything. It‚Äôs build to rate certain types of risks and use that to report back to MDM platforms in order for those platforms to perform an action.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-16 14:17:07

Thanks for confirming. I‚Äôd be interested though in understanding how Duo manages to block access to apps based on certain conditions.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-16 14:18:41

Most likely app wrapping as suggested by others

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-07-17 10:53:34

XenMobile MAM-only is indeed App wrapping. It only works for their own and MDX enabled apps (MDX being their container/mam technology). But Duo sounds like a IdP. I am assuming here, but it sounds like they require some kind of modern authentication apps, connecting to their IDP and some kind of (VPN-less) Access Gateway to the internal resources. The Duo mobile app, which performs authentication, seems to be the agent that actually checks the device posture (i.e. is a password set, etc.) All assumptions based on the info on their website, I do not have any experience with their product(s)

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-07-17 15:15:58

Sounds good @Mark Vonk

Ash Armitt (ashleyarmitt@gmail.com)
2018-07-18 06:28:57

@Ash Armitt has joined the channel

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-07-18 14:42:39

Anyone ever faced a case where Microsoft Exchange teams had to apply the following fix on the servers? https://eightwone.com/2015/12/22/http-proxy-targetbackend-limits/

EighTwOne (821)
} Michel de Rooij (https://eightwone.com/author/mdrooij/)
HTTP Proxy TargetBackEnd¬†limits
Last Update: February 4th, 2016 When deploying Exchange 2013 or Exchange 2016 in co-existence with a legacy version of Exchange, there comes a point where all traffic is routed through Exchange 2013/2016. Traffic for mailboxes hosted on legacy Exchange versions will be proxied by Exchange 2013/2016 to the back end. This proxy process has some built-in limits for certain protocols, which you could encounter. Symptoms of these limits are Event 2022&rsquo;s being logged in the Application log by the MSExchange Front End HTTP Proxy service: Per Exchange 2013 CU7, this message should be considered a notice, despite the confusing event description. No connections are being blocked. However, the events create noise in your logs, which can be prevented by raising these limits. To accomplish this, you need to dive in to the web.config of the applicable HTTP Proxy protocols: $ExInstall\FrontEnd\HttpProxy\sync\web.config (for ActiveSync, EAS) $ExInstall\FrontEnd\HttpProxy\rpc\web.config (for OA, RPC/http) In those files, create or adjust the entry in the appsettings&gt; configuration node, where is the limit you want to configure (default is 150): &rdquo; /&gt; After adjusting these values, recycle the relevant application pools, e.g. MSExchangeSyncAppPool and MSExchangeRPCProxyAppPool. The above steps need to be performed on all Exchange 2013/2016 Client Access Servers. To automate this process of tedious editing in web.config files, I have created a small script which lets you alter these values for EAS and RPC against the local server or remotely. The script, Configure-HTTPProxyTargetBackEnd.ps1, has the following parameters: Server to specify server to configure. When omitted, will configure local server. AllServers to process all discoverable Exchange Client Access servers TargetBackEnd specifies Target Backend limit (default 150). NoRecycle to prevent recycling the MSExchangeSyncAppPool and MSExchangeRPCProxyAppPool For example, to configure the local server with a limit of 2000 for Exchange Active-Sync and RPC access, use: .\Configure-HTTPProxyTargetBackEnd.ps1 -TargetBackEnd 2000 Note that the script will create a backup copy of the web.config files before editing, using the current timestamp. DownloadYou can download the script from the TechNet Gallery here. FeedbackFeedback is welcomed through the comments. If you got scripting suggestions or questions, do not hesitate using the contact form. RevisionSee TechNet Gallery page.
Original URL: https://eightwone.com/2015/12/22/http-proxy-targetbackend-limits/
RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-07-20 18:30:40

Any progress with Outlook caller name resolution with sync disabled?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-07-20 19:32:08

*Thread Reply:* Not something I've seen a case for. What's the reason you wouldn't let the numbers sync to the local address book? I've not seen it on the roadmap.

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-07-20 21:17:12

*Thread Reply:* GDPR compliance! You are not only syncing the number but also the name which is a direct violation! I know that MS does not see this as a use case, still one of the main reason why most of the customers will not use Outlook!

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-07-21 21:33:36

*Thread Reply:* I've heard the gdpr argument for this one before, also around the WhatsApp use of your contacts etc, I'm yet to be convinced though as no one has been able to point me to any compelling part of the Compliance which would apply.

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-07-22 19:59:45

*Thread Reply:* It states in the regulation that synchronizing personal data into a third country (like USA e.g WhatsApp) without consent is a violation. I know the rest of it is pretty wide open for interpretation but at least this one should be clear. What‚Äôs not so clear is if a signed company agreement by the user would be enough for a company to be legally safe again - I doubt it, but thats for lawyers to decide! üòä But let‚Äôs be honest, since iOS 11.3 and higher brings us this cool new feature to protect business contacts from being exposed to unmanaged apps, no need for Outlook anyway! Except DLP use cases of course!

‚úÖ Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-21 00:05:11

@Mark Vonk besides Microsoft‚Äôs SDK/Controls just are built in to their in-house apps and conditional access rules for trusted apps on managed devices, is there anything they provide that anyone else isn‚Äôt doing?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-07-21 07:37:08

*Thread Reply:* In general? Or specific to your earlier question? In general, I do not think Intune is on par with the solutions from Airwatch or Mobileiron. But when used in the MS ecosphere (if you mainly want UEM to manage the Microsoft Cloud and mobile apps), it does offer an advantage; pretty easy to configure and what‚Äôs needed is there. If you want to manage something outside of that, it‚Äôs lacking features or has very basic options at the most. I tend to think of it the following way; with MobileIron (main time spent on that UEM) I have 2 or 3 ways to solve a problem or question. With Intune I either have one possibility or none. I find myself spending a lot of time going lower-level (custom payloads) and out-of-the-box trying to solve something I can easily do with MobileIron. So more workarounds to get something almost similar. I also find that Microsoft (and its employees) lack common mobility knowledge and by that do not seem to have a good grasp of what is asked and needed by customers.

üëå Woody, NicolasR, Damian
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-07-23 13:52:05

*Thread Reply:* I was going as more of a follow-up to my previous question. Great response, either way!

TechCrunch
Cisco is buying Duo Security for $2.35B in cash
Cisco today announced its intention to buy Ann Arbor, MI-based security firm, Duo Security. Under the terms of the agreement, Cisco is paying $2.35 billion in cash and assumed equity awards for Duo. Duo Security was founded in 2010 by Dug Song and Jonathan Oberheide and went on to raise $121.M thro‚Ä¶

Leon (leonashtonleatherland16@gmail.com)
2018-08-26 09:24:42

@Simon Hardy-Bistagne I am not sure it is possible for Intune to tell the difference in the case of the Outlook App. It can for a deployed Gmail or Ninework email config profile as it associates the EAS ID with the AZURE AD ID of the device. Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-09-15 19:48:06

Anyone using intune might wanna buckle up Monday morning for the iOS 12 drop.

Known issue: We're posting this in the Office Message Center regarding a known issue with native mail (this does not affect the Outlook app for iOS). There‚Äôs a known issue with iOS 12, EAS, and conditional access policies. Customers whose end users update to iOS 12 immediately on the September 17th expected iOS 12 availability may find that their iOS native mail app is blocked by conditional access even if they meet the criteria to pass the policies. While a fix is in production in Exchange, it is rolling out as part of the safe rollout process, so it‚Äôs possible for at most a 48-hour period after iOS releases that conditional access policies will need to be adjusted by the MDM admin to ensure continued email access on iOS devices.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-09-15 19:48:30

https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/intunesupport/2018/09/12/support-tip-intune-support-for-ios-12/

Alex Chappuis (alexandre.chappuis@nomasis.ch)
2018-10-11 09:42:06

Hi, I'm referring to previous messages about Intune MAM UPN enforcement for Office365 apps (June 2018, see previous threads #ios_general). I noticed that there is a nice blocker when you are using a third-party MDM (e.g. MobileIron) and Outlook on iOS + Intune MAM mode. Basically, the MDM can define the appConfig for Outlook (server address, email etc.), but you cannot send a second managed configuration for the user UPN enforcement in parallel - only 1 managed configuration is supported for Outlook, this is expected. On Android Enterprise there is a field called "Allowed Accounts" that you don't find the iOS Outlook appconfig. I would love to see the same field on iOS

Do you have the same challenge? maybe this will change with future versions of Outlook. For the time being, it means that a user could be prevented to add a personal account in Outlook for Android, but not in Outlook for iOS! am I right?

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-10-11 18:43:19

No the one I have is to set the UPN For Office365 accounts...

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-15 15:24:33

OK Intune users... Question/Rant coming up...

I want to setup different app protect policies for managed, and unmanaged devices. I want to have unmanaged devices requiring a password to access the MS apps, but managed/enrolled devices to not require an app password (instead relying on a device password).

I have created the policy in the app protect settings page, and made it apply to unamanegd devices only.

Problem i have is that it's being applied to managed device too for some reason.

After lengthy calls with MS, they've told me that I must push an AppConfig setting (the users UPN) to all apps on the device for Intune to recognise that that app is on a managed device. (that's 20 new, individual appconfig policies if anyones counting)

They've also told me that Intune is unable to push an AppConfig setting to an app if is has been installed from the public appstore, and that it must be installed from the company portal app store to be able to managed, and have an AppConfig setting pushed.

Has anyone else seen this kind of behaviour?? I"m sure AirWatch and MobileIron can both take ownership of apps, and push AppConfig settings to apps installed from the public appstores.

aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2018-10-15 15:27:23

AirWatch setting:

aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2018-10-15 15:27:28
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-15 15:28:23

Yep... that's the box i showed the MS engineer i was just having the screen share with... he insisted it was an iOS limitation... he even got out MS paint and drew a pretty picture.

aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2018-10-15 16:10:59
aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2018-10-15 16:11:00

https://developer.apple.com/enterprise/documentation/MDM-Protocol-Reference.pdf

Matthew Shaver (mshaver@us.ibm.com)
2018-10-15 17:06:42

It sounds like their may be some confusion on MS end. They are right that if a user just grabs an app from the store it won‚Äôt receive app config settings, but it sounds like whomever you are speaking to is not familiar with the idea of managed app takeover. I haven‚Äôt used intune, but if they don‚Äôt have any explicit settings for automatically doing this, it may be just a matter of going in to their app catalog and tapping the app install for it to trigger the notification, or ‚Äúre-pushing‚Äù it from the portal side for silent takeovers on qualified devices.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-15 17:52:35

Some "interesting" test results...

So... non MS apps installed from the appstore will recieve appconfig settings. MS apps like yammer teams etc will not.

However..

There is the option in the app config settings in intune to deploy config settings to unmanaged devices. So they're telling me if intune manages they device they can't do app config on MS apps, but they can is intune doesn't manage the device??

I'm lost.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-10-15 18:56:53

It's hard to deal with MS "mobility" engineers... They are (still) lacking the experience. Had to send so many links to Apple and Google documentation pointing out how things should work, it's embarrassing sometimes.

üò≥ Woody
üòÇ Herman
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-17 11:51:36

So...

MS does use the ChangeManagementState but only for apps marked as "required".

For apps which are only marked as "Available" in the appstore, it will not take over management unless the user manually reinstalls the app from the intune appstore over the app you installed form the public appstore.

Similar question... anyone have a full list of the token types that Intune supports.

I know of the following published here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/app-configuration-policies-managed-app#configuration-values-for-using-tokens

{{userprincipalname}} {{mail}} {{partialupn}} {{accountid}} {{userid}} {{username}} {{PrimarySMTPAddress}}

But I also know that's definitely not a full list

docs.microsoft.com
Configuration policies for managed apps without device enrollment
Learn how to configure policies for managed apps without device enrollment.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/app-configuration-policies-managed-app#configuration-values-for-using-tokens
RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-10-19 18:32:58

Guys, Can someone explain the device enrollment restriction to me: quote:‚ÄúIf you block personal Android work profile enrollment, only corporate Android devices can enroll as Android work profile.‚Äú so the corporate identifiers needs to be configured, right? Does this also work for iOS?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-19 18:33:52

Yes that's right.

Unless the device enrolls either through dep, or you've input the IMEI or serial prior to enrollment then it will be blocked

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-19 18:36:09

I don't know though how this would impact kme or zero touch though, and I don't believe they sync and serial data to intune.

I expect it would block them until you entered the IMEI or serial into the admin portal.

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-10-26 13:21:41

Is there any support for Seamless Single Sign-On for On-Premise applications like Sharepoint, Webservers,‚Ä¶ with Intune? Use case like with MobileIron: Web@Work Kerberos Constrained Delegation for Sharepoint on iOS

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-26 13:26:23

Depends how you're carrying out authentication. You can use something like certificate authentication for SSO.

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-10-26 13:36:27

How would you configure Cert Based Auth for Sharepoint within Intune? Which browser?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-26 13:38:35

For us we use Ping as our Idp, so we would set sharepoint to redirect all auth traffic to Ping as the Idp, and the ping would be setup in policy to accept user based certificates for authentication.

I dont have much experience with ADFS however I can only assume it would be a similar process by allowing authentication via user based cert.

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-10-26 13:46:03

Ok sound logical if Sharepoint is setup for SAML. So does the user need to choose a certificate for login?

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-10-26 13:47:06

Where do you use it - iOS and Android Enterprise? Safari, Chrome, Intune Browser?

RobE (robert.kreuzer@outlook.com)
2018-10-26 13:49:38

I know there that CBA for Exchange ActiveSync can be configured, but I have no idea how you would configure CBA for other applications like a browser.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-26 13:50:51

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/authentication/active-directory-certificate-based-authentication-ios

docs.microsoft.com
Azure Active Directory certificate-based authentication on iOS
Learn about the supported scenarios and the requirements for configuring certificate-based authentication in solutions with iOS devices
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/authentication/active-directory-certificate-based-authentication-ios
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-26 13:51:30

this would extend to the sharepoint app too

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-26 13:52:11

Thisi s for all other ADFS apps, but i believe it will prompt the user for a cert

docs.microsoft.com
Configure AD FS support for user certificate authentication
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-fs/operations/configure-user-certificate-authentication
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-10-26 13:52:36

onires53 (jason.r.serino@gmail.com)
2018-11-06 19:28:30

Anyone able to get In tune Graph using Mobile iron to recognize the iOS native mail client in order to open into and send as an attachment. We currently have it set to only allow allow app transfer to other policy managed apps

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-11-06 19:51:20

iOS native mail is not a policy managed app (ie an Intune sdk app). Your policy is blocking it now. Assuming you want use OneDrive or such an app to play nice with the native apps, you can‚Äôt use that policy. You should set it to allow all apps and use managed vs unmanaged iOS restrictions. That is; if the Exchange account is managed (pushed by MI) too.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-11-06 19:52:40

Or use Outlook as the mail client, which is a policy managed app.

onires53 (jason.r.serino@gmail.com)
2018-11-06 20:08:45

The Exchange config is pushed by MI. That might work. We'll give that a shot.

onires53 (jason.r.serino@gmail.com)
2018-11-06 20:30:18

Yeah. Problem is that we need a way to have the attachments being opened into Docs@Work to open into the Office apps but force it to use Corp persona and not allow to open using personal personas. I thought there was a way to make that happen. Has anyone done it before?

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-11-06 22:43:41

There is a way but you need MobileIron Access to manage native mail client conditional access

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-11-06 22:44:09

The to force attachments to open in Docs@work you can use managed open-in restrictions available in MobileIron

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-11-06 22:45:50

To force corporate persona on Office apps I don't think you can do it when attachment comes from Docs@work

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-11-06 22:46:25

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-11-08 19:33:15

@onires53 You might want to check the following article: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/data-transfer-between-apps-manage-ios Maybe this helps you in your use-case. If so, you can deploy the IntuneMAMUPN to the Microsoft Office apps using MobileIron. When you "Open In" a document from Docs@Work in an Office app, the corporate persona (based on UPN) will be used and not the personal.

docs.microsoft.com
Manage transferring data between iOS apps
Understand how to use mobile app management policies in Microsoft Intune to manage data transfers between apps.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/data-transfer-between-apps-manage-ios
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-11-08 19:42:09

Also, check this article on how to do it on Core: https://community.mobileiron.com/message/6126

Noncompliant message and actions with Microsoft Intune - Azure
Create a notification email to send to non-compliant devices. Add actions after a device is marked as non-compliant, such as add a grace period to get compliant, or create a schedule to block access until the device is compliant. Do this using Microsoft Intune in Azure.

onires53 (jason.r.serino@gmail.com)
2018-11-28 23:26:58

Hey Guys.... Finishing up our Intune Managed Apps setup using MobileIron for the MDM. Everything is working as expected. However we are trying to get native iOS mail attachments to open into the Office Apps but only in the corporate persona. Evidently this can be done through a iOS Managed App config .plist that only allows 3rd party apps to open into the corporate persona. We have had a few discussions with MI on this as they have shown it can be done (https://vimeo.com/270419016) but we have yet to be successful.

The config works to open the MS app and log the associate into their corporate persona if it is not setup already, however if the associate has a personal and Corp persona setup it still allows the associate to choose which persona to upload the documents to regardless without DLP controls.

Vimeo
} MobileIron (https://vimeo.com/mobileiron)
Securing Multi-Identity Office 365 apps on iOS Email
Original URL: https://vimeo.com/270419016
Amine (amine.ayad@gmail.com)
2018-11-28 23:33:13

I planed on testing this on Friday, I think it‚Äôs more about the document‚Äôs protection using AIP. The document is flagged to only be opened using the user‚Äôs or organization‚Äôs account (domain name).

Nicola (nicola.aloise@nomasis.ch)
2018-11-30 11:46:49

@onires53 We are testing also since 2 months and it's not working for us. We have opened a ticket with our customer and the feedback was: If you managed to get the same results repro-wise, then the system works as intended.

MAM policies protect work resources only within the targeted apps: Mobile Onedrive and Outlook are included, Safari and the native mail app on iOS are not.

For a full list of MAM supported apps, see: https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/cloud-platform/microsoft-intune-apps

Microsoft Cloud-Platform - GB (English)
Microsoft Intune Apps | Microsoft
Find apps enhanced with mobile application management policies in the Microsoft Intune mobile apps gallery.
Original URL: https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/cloud-platform/microsoft-intune-apps
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-11-30 12:39:40

One thing we‚Äôve noticed is that if you open the policy up using config settings then you need to install the app through the company portal to make it managed.

Unlike other mdm which manage an app when you install it from the App Store, you must install it via the company portal before it will allow app config to take place.

The only exception is ‚Äúrequired‚Äù apps which it will take management off.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-12-07 09:57:22

*Thread Reply:* Once migrated, users leveraging the native Microsoft sync technology will have access to all current features and functionality as well as new ones as they roll out on the updated architecture (e.g., such as Microsoft 365 Roadmap feature IDs 32570 S/MIME or 32572 Shared Mailbox).

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-12-07 09:58:27

*Thread Reply:* We were informed by our MS bod that this will all start rolling out from the start of December, and once the updateso n the EOL side are done, and the new version of Outlook drops, these features will be avaialbe.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2018-12-07 10:35:20

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, found it and forwarded it to our TAM!

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2018-12-03 20:32:25

Great!

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-12-05 14:34:03

Intune policies update authentication method and Company Portal app installation Intune will no longer support the Company Portal app when it is installed from the App store, on certain devices. This change is only relevant when you authenticate with Apple Setup Assistant during enrollment. This change also only affects iOS devices enrolled through:

Apple configurator Apple Business Manager Apple School Manager Apple Device Enrollment Program (DEP) If users install the Company Portal app from the App store, and then try to enroll these devices through it, they will receive an error. These devices will be expected to only use Company Portal when it's been pushed, automatically, by Intune during enrollment. Enrollment profiles in Intune in the Azure portal will be updated so that you can specify how devices authenticate and if they receive the Company Portal app. If you want your DEP device users to have the Company Portal, you will need to specify your preferences in an enrollment profile. In addition, the Identify your device screen in the Company Portal app will soon become obsolete. To install Company Portal on already-enrolled DEP devices, you will need to go to Intune > Client apps, and push it as a managed app with app configuration policies. Details about how to do these steps will be outlined in future docs.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-12-05 14:37:23

For anyone deploying Outlook into an Android Enteprise work profile container... you MUST set the following permissions, otherwise you will not be able to sync your contacts from Outlook, to the local device.

üëç Tycho, Mark Vonk

if you don't set (forcibly) either auto grant, or prompt... it doesn't actually request them all properly... so you have to force the settings down.

Hi all, just wanted to make you aware that the fully managed devices / COBO solution set support within Intune has been delayed until January. It kinda has been announced by Microsoft but not a very clear announcement IMHO Its kind of been bundled with a "this is how good were are" statement https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/Enterprise-Mobility-Security/How-does-Microsoft-Intune-transform-Android-enterprise/ba-p/299289 I have also tried to get some kind of date from the PG regarding COPE but they are remaining tight lipped at the moment, I am led to believe that it should soon follow

TECHCOMMUNITY.MICROSOFT.COM
How does Microsoft Intune transform Android enterprise management? Let me count the ways
With Android Enterprise, Google raises the bar for management of mobile devices and services. Additional management capabilities and improved consistency across the Android ecosystem enable you to confidently deploy Android devices in your enterprise. From the enterprise mobility management (EMM) pe...
Original URL: https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/Enterprise-Mobility-Security/How-does-Microsoft-Intune-transform-Android-enterprise/ba-p/299289

2019-01-25 17:33:49

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-01-25 17:35:10

Yes, changes in mam policys can take (if I remember correctly) up to 6 hours to take effect.

üòÆ NicolasR
NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:19:00

*Thread Reply:* what's this 6 to 8 hours delay to apply a policy?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-01-28 09:22:37

*Thread Reply:* Maximum if the application has not been opened.

If the app is open, it refreshes every 30 mins... If the app hasn't been opened after 30 mins, it will refresh the next time it opened, or after 8 hours which ever comes first

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:23:54

*Thread Reply:* It's akward, isn't it?

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:24:03

*Thread Reply:* 30 minutes to apply a security policy?

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:24:17

*Thread Reply:* it means that your data are exposed during 30 minutes...

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:24:23

*Thread Reply:* ü§î

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-01-28 09:24:58

*Thread Reply:* Well that's to apply a change in policy...

For a new enrolment then it will pickup the policy straight away (or should do at least)

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:25:58

*Thread Reply:* ok, that's better indeed

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-28 09:26:17

*Thread Reply:* I was afraid that new enrollments don't get the newest policy

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-01-25 17:36:13

Just checked... It's 8 hours unless the app is opened.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-01-25 17:36:28

App protection policies - Policy refresh Apps check in to the APP service every 30 minutes. The 30-minute threshold is based on a timer. If the app is active at 30 minutes, it checks in at 30 minutes. If the app is sleeping at 30 minutes, it checks in on the next focus. If no policy is assigned to a user, check-in occurs every eight hours. If no Intune license is assigned, check-in occurs every 24 hours.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2019-01-25 17:55:07

Outlook is connecting to O365 mailboxes in this instance.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2019-01-25 17:55:26

The app is definitely being opened so the policy should be applied ;)

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2019-01-25 17:55:57

So it‚Äôs a bug or some sort

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-01-25 18:00:09

It‚Äôs only guaranteed to work with an account that uses modern auth, Intune app protection depends on the identity of the user to be consistent between the application and the Intune App SDK. The only way to guarantee that is through modern authentication. That‚Äôs why I asked.

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2019-01-25 18:06:37

We use modern auth

Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2019-01-29 15:47:54

Anyone any info from MSFT regarding the ability to restrict use of personal accounts within Outlook either by a MAM setting or AppConfig. I heard AppConfig is coming but I think it‚Äôs an important feature to take into consideration especially for iOS supervised devices

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-01-29 16:13:36

I saw something like this yesterday on MobileIron core... I was wondering what it was about

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-01-29 16:18:20

The feature was released last weekend.

Additional settings for Outlook

You can now configure additional settings for Outlook for iOS and Android using Intune. The settings include the following: Only allow work or school accounts to be used in Outlook in iOS and Android Deploy modern authentication for Office 365 and hybrid modern authentication on-premises accounts Use SAMAccountName for the username field in the email profile when basic authentication is selected Allow contacts to be saved Configure external recipients MailTips Configure Focused Inbox Require biometrics to access Outlook for iOS Block external images

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-12 11:11:29

How can we make our iOS Inhouse app an ‚ÄûApproved App‚Äú so we can use it with Conditional Access? Wrapping Tool is not the way, right? (Only for App Protection Policies)

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-12 11:58:12

*Thread Reply:* What are you looking to allow it to do?

The ‚Äúapproved app‚Äù function in conditional access is designed for MS to allow only their apps access into certain MS services. Eg, only the official Outlook app can access your mailfile.

It‚Äôs designed so that you can guarantee that the app will abide by all the MAM policies.

If you want your internal app on that list, it‚Äôs never gunna happen frankly.

If though, you‚Äôre just looking to add your in-house app to the list of apps which you can share data between through mam policy, then you can add it manually at the bottom of the mam apps selection screen in intune.

I‚Äôd suggest you at least wrap it though so that it doesn‚Äôt become an exfiltration point for your users to pass data through.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-12 12:02:07

*Thread Reply:* Right, We would like to do the same like what can be done with the Outlook app or the Intune Managed browser - user are only allowed to use the Managed Browser or the Outlook app - require approved client app feature within Conditional Access. Is this only for MS cloud services? We need this for an on-prem service

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-12 12:07:22

*Thread Reply:* So as long as azure if your idp you can add the 3rd part app and use azure as the Sso.

Tbh you‚Äôre not going to be able to do that through CA as it is by default.

This is something that I would expect has to be added through azure ad as a custom rule set, but it‚Äôs not going to be massively secure if that‚Äôs what your concern is.

You‚Äôd have to create a custom rules et to look for the app headers and set a rule to say that only an app with that header can access that server app.

It‚Äôs not best practice though as headers can be spoofed.

Is the on prem app you‚Äôre trying to access via your in-house app accessable via the internet?

If not, then your best bet is to use the app proxy config, and apply it only to the managed in-house app.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-12 20:40:00

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Simon, I will give it a try üôè

Martin Hiller√∂ (martin.hillero@techstep.se)
2019-02-13 13:51:09

Why are some settings of a DeviceConfig profile not applied to a COBO device? I know it's still in preview but the options available right now should be working right? Created an Android Enterprise profile, assigned to All Devices (so all Android Enterprise devices are targetted). Setup device password and 10min lock screen time. Both are not applied on the device. Device is enrolled as DO, user is not logged in CompanyPortal app. When user logs in the CompanyPortal app the Android policies are applied (not Android Enterprise) and the user has 2 devices registered, 1x Android Enterprise (company owned) and 1x Android(personal owned) while it's in fact the same device.

Marc van der Kooy (marc.vanderkooy@gmail.com)
2019-02-13 15:02:03

In the COBO preview, the user has to login while doing the DO device setup. Intune recognizes the user and "links" the device to the user in Intune. So far so good. After completing the setup. Required apps are pushed within a few minutes. Even App Config Policies are applied on the installed apps. But that's it. No Android Enterprise Device Configuration policies are applied. You need to create an Android policy(while it is an Android Enterprise device), apply it to the user. Let the user login in the Company Portal app, install MDM profile etc Then Intune will apply the Android (Not enterprise) Device Configuration and asks the user to setup a passcode. It also assigns a new device(personal, Android) to the user so it has 2 devices registered...

Marc van der Kooy (marc.vanderkooy@gmail.com)
2019-02-13 15:02:57

So 1 physical device is now 2x enrolled in Intune. 1x Android Enterprise - Company device 1x Android - Personal device

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-16 08:01:20

Is there really no way to disable location tracking for personal devices within Intune? üò≥

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 08:06:20

As far as I‚Äôm aware location tracking isn‚Äôt available at all in intune unless the device is supervised.

Ms implement a lot of limits on what you can do and see on personal devices. There is no admin control to adjust you just have to go with what ms see fit.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 08:12:13

Are you referring to the security prompt when first enrolling that company portal is using your location??

This will be due to you having enhanced jailbreak detection enabled in the global compliance policy setting which uses a change in the users location to trigger an early security check.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-16 08:16:59

No I meant the location tracking feature that you have mentioned for supervised devices. The problem with that is: BYOD devices can also be supervised. We have a lot of engineers who supervised their personal devices. So legally I am not allowed to track these devices, but technically I can‚Äôt prevent it to locate these devices from the Intune console.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 08:27:10

You have supervised byo devices?

Wow...!?

How do they currently flag in the intune console? As personal?

You have a couple of options but nothing that‚Äôs 100%

Options that spring to mind are that you ‚Äútag‚Äù these devices as ‚Äúdon‚Äôt track‚Äù, and then flag in your admins permissions a new set just for that tag that they don‚Äôt have permission to press the track button.

I also wonder if you might be able to script something that can change the supervised flag based on ownership (eg, any device makes byo, change the supervised market).

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-16 08:48:42

Good idea, thanks. Yes we have bought out a company of 500 people where most of the software engineers supervise their own devices with AC2. Weird! üò≥

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2019-02-16 08:50:52

@Peter Mohr has joined the channel

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 08:59:38

You're far kinder than me!

Is there a reason they need to do that for their job?

I'd frankly have them adopt our security position for their devices don't get enrolled. Having a supervisor profile on their device you don't manage introduces masses of risk which I personally wouldn't be comfortable with.

If the device need supervisor mode, and they need the device for their work, then logically they should get a corporate device.

üôè MichaelM21
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 09:01:23

But.? I'm sure there are political pieces at play

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-16 15:07:35

*Thread Reply:* Yes, totally political. But we are in the process of moving them over to corporate owned devices. But in terms of location tracking, we are also facing the issue with our union rep that it is prohibited to track devices in our company, which will also hit the corporate owned supervised devices. Hopefully RBAC for tracking will be enough.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 15:41:52

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, just remember that it's not "tracking" as it only ever kicks in when you enter the device into lost mode. You cant obtain a location without this, so the user will always be aware of anyone ever used it.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-02-16 16:23:41

*Thread Reply:* Seriously? The device has to be in Lost Mode for tracking? üò≥ but this could solve some issues

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-16 16:25:19

*Thread Reply:* Yes, the only way you‚Äôre able (through Intune) to have the device report its location is to kick it into lost mode, locking the user out until you remove lost mode.

It‚Äôs all part of the privacy stance ms are running with. So not really tracking, more finding a lost device.

üëç MichaelM21
aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2019-02-16 14:49:30

For those engineers who supervise their devices, perhaps give them a list of everything your MDM can control on their BYOD device, and that may scare them into removing supervision. Location tracking, silently adding and removing apps, disable iCloud and email accounts, and a bunch more. To remove supervision they should back up to iCloud and erase device. That should work.

Bilgin (bilginbaldji@yahoo.co.uk)
2019-02-21 23:03:59

*Thread Reply:* @System Admin Last week I was looking at the stale entries of my test devices that have been wiped numerous times. What I've noticed in the output of Get-MsolDevice is that the DeviceObjectVersion property is 1 for devices that have been wiped in Intune and respectively do not show in the "All Devices" list, but you can find them in "Azure AD Devices" list with Owner: None, MDM: Intune, Compliant/Registered/Activity: N/A The full command was: Get-MsolDevice -All -IncludeSystemManagedDevices | Where-Object {$_.DeviceObjectVersion -eq 1} I've cross-checked random devices to make sure I'm not about to nuke legit Workplace Registered devices (which do have Owner field set correctly) and it looked good. Nevertheless I cannot find any info on DeviceObjectVersion property, so take my words with a pinch of salt. As for the permissions Cloud Device Administrator is what you might be looking for, haven't tested it.

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-25 12:04:59

Intune deploying one scep cert together with every single profile, (so basically I have a WiFi, a VPN, an exchange and a SSO profile). I have now 4 times the same cert on the iOS device. Safari simply goes mad when trying to authenticate against my (SSO) website, because it does not know which one to switch to. Can anyone confirm a valid setup for SSO on Intune (iOS)?

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-25 12:09:34

*Thread Reply:*

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-25 12:11:58

*Thread Reply:* Have you tried changing the Subject Name in the SCEP config (set it to custom). That way, you can diversify the names of the client certificates.

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-25 12:33:00

*Thread Reply:* Hi Mark, yes. Did that. Since the website authentication (F5) checks for the issuer and all cetrts are coming from the PKI, I have this behaviour. Not seen in MI but there the SSO cert comes from the core's local CA.

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-25 12:34:38

*Thread Reply:* But several profiles in MI are using the same scep cert (embedded) without the need to deploy a separate one for each of them

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 06:08:57

*Thread Reply:* That is weird indeed. I would assume the behavior is the same between Intune and Mobileiron, in both cases the certs come from the CA. But the on device experience is different?

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-26 07:55:19

*Thread Reply:*

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-26 07:56:06

*Thread Reply:*

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-26 07:57:12

*Thread Reply:* There's is a difference on how SCEP are treated. MI treats them as Cert, Intune as Device Identity Cert... mmm...

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 00:14:29

We‚Äôre curious about MAM via InTune and endpoint management with Workspace ONE UEM for iOS and Android only. Is there anyone here that can give any feedback on open issues or gaps that they have experienced?

üëç Woody, Tycho
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2019-02-26 03:30:23

*Thread Reply:* Funny, I was just speaking to someone about this approach the other day

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2019-02-26 03:35:32

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd think iOS is self explanatory. Would be curious how it plays out on Android. Guessing MAM apps would reside outside the work profile, etc?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 06:11:11

*Thread Reply:* Works in a Work profile too. Only real thing for the policies to be effectuated on Android: make sure you use the MAM apps with modern auth and you also need the Intune Company Portal app on Android (installed is enough, does not need to be registered)

üëç JF Rigot
Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-02-26 12:07:58

*Thread Reply:* This is what we do currently. We offer the option of enrollment though WS1 or users van choose to have MAM only. As Mark says the company portal app is required for MAM which causes some confusion for users who try to enroll (which fails because don't have this allowed). Yes it works in a work profile but if you use pure MAM without enrollment then of course you won't have one.

Let me know if you have practical questions!

üëç Woody
jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 16:24:56

*Thread Reply:* I think we‚Äôre trying to understand why you would use two management services to try to accomplish the same thing. Access management is key for us but we would want to ensure there was some level of device management before we would allow access into their microsoft account via InTune. But this just isn‚Äôt possible if you don‚Äôt enroll the device fully in InTune. We also see how the auth token is replayed for any Office app regardless of management. So that is concerning.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 16:32:56

*Thread Reply:* You do not need to enroll in Intune for ensuring device management. Intune is an easy solution to accomplish that (depending on the situation: conditional access and MAM even with Intune is not always as straightforward and there are it‚Äôs and but‚Äôs) but you can accomplish the same with other EMMs. In some cases it might be slightly more complex, but then again, those other EMMs are typically much more advanced than Intune. So you gain a lot on the EMM front

üëç Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2019-02-26 17:46:19

*Thread Reply:* Are there not DLP controls for the Office apps that are exclusive to InTune controls? Or were they all made available via the Graph API?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 18:00:48

*Thread Reply:* I have not seen any difference with respect to MAM and DLP controls between Intune and the Graph API.

üëç Woody, JF Rigot
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2019-02-26 18:42:15

*Thread Reply:* Nice. Are there any ‚Äúenterprise class‚Äù EMMs that have not integrated the Graph API at this point?

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 18:44:23

*Thread Reply:* You can set policy in the EMM, but InTune admin access to those same policies will override what is set by the EMM. It‚Äôs only one way integration. There isn‚Äôt a bi-directional integration for the EMM.

ü§î Woody
jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 18:44:55

*Thread Reply:* Which in my mind makes it pointless to integrate in the first place.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 18:49:20

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you can manage them from Intune too. You do not have to do it from your other EMM. But it does not invalidate any reason to manage the devices from a different EMM.

üëç Woody
jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 18:59:56

*Thread Reply:* Clear source of truth for policy management is where it would turn into an organizational issue and potential support problem. When you have to manage this for 6 figures of people across geographies, we want the most straight forward method of enablement with the least amount of risk and overhead. I‚Äôm not seeing that come to light with a co-managed approach.

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 19:00:33

*Thread Reply:* Am I missing a component between Workspace ONE UEM and InTune?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 19:46:40

*Thread Reply:* I would not know as I am not knowledgeable on Workspace One. This thread has gone from specific to more high level and back. What I wrote is general, not specific. There are lots of organizations on Intune. But there are better EMMs in the market currently. It all depends on what your organization want to do with and if Intune can fulfill the needs. It all depends on the business and use cases. Sure, it might be more complex to do co-managed, but it also might offer more features or a better user experience. As for MAM policies only; I would not call this complex at all, with a 3rd party or with Intune. There are a couple of basic settings. You will not be changing those frequently, for most orgs it‚Äôs a set and forget exercise. Number of devices does not necessarily introduce complexity. I have seen very small orgs with very complex infra and setups and very large ones with very simple setups. Again, for Microsoft MAM, it will never get that complicated, even with large orgs and complex setups.

üëç Woody
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-26 20:15:55

*Thread Reply:* Actually thinking about it; a large, global environment in Intune is somewhat more challenging than other EMMs. Most EMMs have pretty good RBAC these days, which is still challenging in Intune. Furthermore, I do not like how Intune registered devices are sometimes not really managed at all. While being registered in Intune (and having access to apps, etc) these devices are not actually, correctly managed in Intune anymore. There are some basic features, but with larger environments and more strict policy control, you will need to script a lot to perform some basic housekeeping. Other EMMs have this build in typically. Anyway imho and fwiw and so on üòâ

üëç Woody, JF Rigot
jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2019-02-26 22:34:54

*Thread Reply:* Mark, thank you. This is helpful to hear.

Kiran Patel (kiran@kiranpatel.net)
2019-02-26 12:52:30

Has anyone tried using ExternalRecipientsToolTipEnabled with Outlook on iOS? Does anyone know if this applies to all mail profiles in the Outlook app or just the Corp one?

JF Rigot (jr@mob.co)
2019-02-27 12:54:30

*Thread Reply:* Not tested yet, but in theory this would be applied to your managed profile only. (so the corp one)

Bilgin (bilginbaldji@yahoo.co.uk)
2019-02-27 16:36:01

*Thread Reply:* Ross Smith from Microsoft did a presentation about Outlook mobile at the Ignite today and I asked him about it. Response was: If it is enabled it affects all Office 365 accounts and Ouath 2.0 enabled hybrid Exchange accounts. He also did a quick demo with his personal account on his mobile and tooltips were shown.

üëç JF Rigot, Kiran Patel
Kiran Patel (kiran@kiranpatel.net)
2019-03-11 04:33:22

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-03-05 19:16:36

I‚Äôve been a long time SOTI Android+ (DA) and more recently Android Enterprise (DO) admin, specifically for Zebra Android devices and have a lot of expertise in that arena. I‚Äôve now started to evaluate Intune more because I hear that MX and OEMConfig support are coming for Zebra devices but have encountered a number of seemingly large functionality gaps for Android COSU / Dedicated device management.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-03-05 20:32:08

*Thread Reply:* COSU and COBO as of yet are only partly developed as Microsoft are waiting for google to release the api integration on their newer cloud api services.

Microsoft don‚Äôt wish to develop using the legacy services which others have done.

It limits their current support sure, but I at least understand it.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-03-05 19:16:53

Is Intune seriously missing Remote Control, remote file retrieval, and file push capabilities?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-03-05 20:29:48

*Thread Reply:* You‚Äôre unlikely to ever have these as intune currently focuses on knowledge worker devices.

Most of the functionality you describe isn‚Äôt supported in the modern way in which google is structured around the modern Android enterprise api set and so Microsoft is unlikely to support it.

üëç Tycho
Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-03-05 19:17:45

I also dont seem to be able to push an enterprise app without distributing it through Managed Play under DO management

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-03-05 20:27:55

*Thread Reply:* Yes you can distribute apps under device admin mode locally hosted, or through managed google play.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2019-03-05 19:18:02

It's missing a fair bit yes

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-03-05 19:18:10

Is anybody actually using Intune in a AE COSU environment with all this missing?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-03-05 19:47:43

For COSU Remote control and file mgmt, is not even the worst thing Intune is missing. There is some basic stuff you can‚Äôt do like manage system apps and apps not in the Public play store. You can workaround remote control and file management with 3rd party solutions. But the basic stuff is hard to fix.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-03-06 11:44:01

I would bet a large sum of money that it‚Äôs the account you‚Äôre using...

Have a check in AAD under the users profile, check out ‚Äúdevices‚Äù and see how many are listed there in total (inc windows machines, and mobile devices).

My guess is that you have reached the 20 device per user limit of AAD.

üëç Tycho, Mark Vonk
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-03-06 11:44:51

Delete a couple of these older devices, and you‚Äôll be able to enrol

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-03-06 11:45:02

Yes indeed, it doesn't auto delete a device once you unenrol it

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-03-06 11:46:22

Remember, this is in AAD, not in the intune portal. Even if you delete a device for the intune portal it doesn‚Äôt replicate fully into the AAD user account,

Most users wont see this as an issue, but if they have even in the company 20 years and had many windows machines, or, you‚Äôre an IT power user constantly swapping PCs or logging into new machines then you‚Äôll get this issue.

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-03-06 16:46:30

Marc van der Kooy (marc.vanderkooy@gmail.com)

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2019-03-06 12:34:52

Any idea how we can control the specific app version update of apple VPP apps via intune emm system like airwatch mdm? If auto update is enabled under vpp token settings under intune tenent.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-03-06 12:38:27

I didnt think version control was an option

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-03-06 12:38:28

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/vpp-apps-ios

docs.microsoft.com
Manage iOS volume-purchased apps in Microsoft Intune
Learn about how you can sync apps you purchased in volume from the iOS store into Microsoft Intune and then manage and track their usage.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/vpp-apps-ios
Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2019-03-06 12:41:24

Automatic app updates - Choose from On or Off to enable automatic updates. When enabled, Intune detects the VPP app updates inside the app store and automatically pushes them to the device when the device checks in. Automatic app updates for Apple VPP apps will automatically update only apps deployed with Required install intent. For apps deployed with Available install intent, the automatic update generates a notification for you (the admin) informing you that a new version of the app is available. The user must click install to install the newer version of the app. Additionally, the user will see that the app as not installed on Company Portal, even though an earlier version of the app is installed. In this case, the user can reinstall the app.

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2019-03-06 12:44:39

I feel this is very sadly by designed my microsoft with respect to vpp app mgmt. We have deployed some public free vpp apps in our tenent with available install option but it not even generating a notification to admins about the new app version availability.

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2019-03-06 12:46:16

And not even showing to update option into company portal. It showing install and re-install the app. (Even its installed on our devices)

Thibaut Bellon (thibaut@mobinergy.com)
2019-03-06 22:05:17

Hi everybody, is there any ADFS guru here? my ADFS is federated with 3rd party IDP and receives urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:status:AuthnFailed from SAML response of the 3rd party IDP. That answer is expected but I want to build a custom claim rule that looks at that error and then asks for ADFS authentication. Any Idea how to build the claim rule? my 3rd party IDP is sending that <samlp:StatusCode Value=‚Äúurn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:status:Responder‚Äù> <samlp:StatusCode Value=‚Äúurn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:status:AuthnFailed‚Äù /> </samlp:StatusCode> <samlp:StatusMessage>IOSDEVICENOT_MANAGED</samlp:StatusMessage> <samlp:StatusDetail>Your device is not managed by the Company. Please register your device to get access to enterprise services</samlp:StatusDetail>

Bilgin (bilginbaldji@yahoo.co.uk)
2019-03-10 13:12:24

Hitting the wall again with Intune regarding SIM card auditing. I'll be glad to hear if your business service providers have the MSIN programmed in the SIM card, but my experience is the field is blank, as cards are getting phone number assigned during activation. Thus reported Phone Number field is usually empty for corporate devices. Which leaves me with ICCID. ICCID is not a queried or reported value in Intune (including MS-Graph or the relevant PowerShell module). Or maybe I can't find the correct query? On top of that, no Subscriber Carrier is reported, which I am not sure what to think about - is Intune trying to read the name from the SPN on the SIM card rather than match the MNC code to the operator? I get both ICCID and operator reported in AirWatch.

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-03-11 13:03:02

Yes we use Authenticator. It works OK but not all applications seem to support it fully yet. For example in Teams and Yammer it still asks me to sign in, but when I put my UPN it then logs in automatically.

Others like Outlook do sign in fully straight away.

Overall it's a big improvement not having to sign in everything separately anymore, considering how many MS apps there are üòâ But it could be better. Please not we use a separate Identity Management solution (PingID) so we don't use the built in one.
