üëç JF Rigot
aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2019-03-11 22:22:14

Does anyone here have experience with MS Graph APIs? I‚Äôve got a dumb(?) question about authentication. I‚Äôm working on a machine-to-machine API, so I can‚Äôt use interactive authentication. This system will also be used for multiple customers. I‚Äôm used to API schemes that include a simple user/pass and maybe an access key. Graph seems to be much more complicated ‚Äî https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-service ‚Äî Can anyone help me understand what the setup experience is like?

docs.microsoft.com
Get access without a user - Microsoft Graph
Some apps call Microsoft Graph with their own identity and not on behalf of a user. In many cases, these are background services or daemons that run on a server without the presence of a signed-in user.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-service
Dani√´l Kraaijeveld (daniel.kraaijeveld@twentynice.com)
2019-03-12 08:05:29

Best way to do this would be via Azure Automation. Although if you‚Äôre are trying to authenticate without prompt via a Windows Server for example there are some possibility‚Äôs.

The most important thing you have to acquire for authentication is your token that is used against Intune/Azure. The Powershell Module PSIntuneAuth takes care of that with just two input variable that are your Azure TenantID and a ps Credential object. You can acquire your TenantID by running connect-AzureAD and it should report your TenantID back after authenticating. For the PS Credential object I‚Äôd recommend creating an encrypted password and then building the credentials from that, you can do that by following this guide: https://www.pdq.com/blog/secure-password-with-powershell-encrypting-credentials-part-2.

If you need an example script, shoot me a message and i‚Äôll send it to you.

PDQ.com
Secure Password with PowerShell: Encrypting Credentials - Part 2 - PDQ.com
Secure password with PowerShell: Learn how to securely encrypt your passwords and automate your PowerShell scripts by using AES keys.
Original URL: https://www.pdq.com/blog/secure-password-with-powershell-encrypting-credentials-part-2
aaron (aaron@groundctl.com)
2019-03-12 08:26:00

Thanks @Dani√´l Kraaijeveld. This isn‚Äôt PowerShell at all. It‚Äôs a web app running on Unix. And I‚Äôm a Mac guy, quite familiar with REST APIs. But this is looking more and more foreign to me.

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-03-12 09:17:07

I'm running into the same thing at the moment too, running scripts against Intune. I have a lot of experience with the AirWatch REST API too. And I know what you mean! I mainly used PHP scripts for AirWatch.

I'm using Powershell for this because I'd like to stay within the native ecosystem and because I wanted to learn it anyway. I'm trying to stick with the MS-supplied applets as much as possible. But I believe their REST API conforms to the oauth 2.0 standard so you should be able to use a library that offers that. It's indeed very complex to do it all by hand.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-03-18 08:35:06

Use Case access to On-Premise CIFS shares (DFS Fileserver) for iOS devices - how would that be implemented with Intune? There is no integrated gateway like with MobileIron (Sentry) or Airwatch which reside in the DMZ. Also the apps which access the file shares should be containerized like MobileIron Docs@Work or Airwatch Content app. Any ideas?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-03-18 08:36:30

Well the Microsoft way would be to use OneDrive (Cloud) and use the OneDrive app with MAM and conditional access

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-03-18 08:41:13

Right, which would mean you would have to publish the internal file servers, like with Web Application Proxy or Azure AD Proxy.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-03-18 08:45:19

Pretty sure the App proxy won‚Äôt be able to proxy CIFS.I will mean you have to start using SharePoint and OneDrive and migrate the data over there.

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-03-18 09:00:29

Pfff On-Premise is soooo 2018.... üòÑ I think you‚Äôll need third party to address this use case

ü§£ MichaelM21, Leon
MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-03-18 09:17:16

All good points, but basically what you are saying is that this use case is not sooo simple to realize like with other real EMMs üòúüòá

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-03-18 10:15:20

InTune is good for Microsoft Cloud use cases. Other use cases InTune is not that good and it‚Äôs not Microsoft‚Äôs strategy. Unfortunately a lot of customers don‚Äôt realize that in the early phases of the projects because Microsoft is pushy to deploy quickly...

üëç MichaelM21, Tycho, JP Guldfeldt
Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)
2019-03-18 12:11:17

Web Application Proxy can be used for conditional access to WebDAV server which can work as ‚Äúabstraction layer‚Äù for CIFS share.

üëç Mark Vonk, MichaelM21, Andrew Olpin

} Ross Smith IV (https://twitter.com/RossSmithIV/status/1112802941143056387)
If you still use ActiveSync, EAS conditional access policy improvements are coming. But remember, <a href="https://twitter.com/Outlook">@Outlook</a> mobile is the only secure productivity mobile client worth using. üòÅ #ems <b>#AzureAD</b> #outlook <b>#MSIntune</b> <https://twitter.com/gregtaylor_msft/status/1112716159952969732>

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2019-04-04 23:23:53

*Thread Reply:* The problem with Outlook for iOS is that it‚Äôs not GDPR compliant... it requires the device to have an iCloud account. You can try by yourself: 1- take a device with ONLY a third party account like Gmail for contacts. (No iCloud account) 2- install and sync outlook for iOS 3- try to export contacts... you can‚Äôt because it requires iCloud...!! 4- add the iCloud account, contacts get synced with iCloud... üëåü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è:skintone3:

Srikanth (srikanth.gone@live.com)
2019-04-04 15:05:01

Hello All, Need a suggestion on Hybrid Intune (SCCM+Intune), we have a compliance policy setting value called 'Idle time before phone locked' set to 1 minute and we got 1000 mobile devices already enrolled with hybrid intune and got this compliance policy. Now, we want to change this compliance policy setting value from 1 minute to 5 minutes, so the question is, Do we need to re-enroll all 1000 mobile devices when this new settings pushed to mobile devices? Or this would be pushed silently to mobile devices without any impact. Please advise

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-04-04 16:13:27

It would be silently pushed

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-04-04 16:14:01

We often change settings to enrolled phones, if it required them to re-enroll for every profile change there wouldn't be much point to having the MDM üòâ

üëç Srikanth
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-04-04 19:14:37

This could have been easily tested also...

Bilgin (bilginbaldji@yahoo.co.uk)
2019-04-04 19:24:06

I have an open ticket with Microsoft for "Maximum minutes of inactivity until screen locks" setting in Intune, which applies successfully if it is set to 15 minutes, but setting it to a different value results in "Not applicable". Samsung phones with Android 8.0.0, odd thing is the setting results in one model displaying maximum time of 13 minutes in the lockscreen menu, whereas another allows 14:30.

Bilgin (bilginbaldji@yahoo.co.uk)
2019-04-07 00:24:24

*Thread Reply:* Turned out the compliance setting "Maximum minutes of inactivity before password is required" is acting like a configuration, applying the limit to the lockscreen time, rather than just assessing if the configured time is compliant with the defined value. When the compliance policy value (Maximum minutes of inactivity before password is required) and the configuration policy value (Maximum minutes of inactivity until screen locks) are different, the latter results in "Not applicable". It doesn't make a lot of sense to me, I would expect compliance policy to be assessing and take action if non-compliant, not to be configuring the device #microsoft_intune

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-05-06 20:54:32

*Thread Reply:* There is no difference between MDM solutions with regard to this issue. As long as the contacts are in the contact system app (so export if from Outlook, Email+, etc or use the gmail apps) in the work profile, it should work. But most of the times, it does not work. I think there might be some dependency with the Carkits and car system in order for it to work. But in 9 of 10 cases I have seen, it does not work It works with Android auto, as far as I have tested, but that works differently.

Marc van der Kooy (marc.vanderkooy@gmail.com)
2019-05-09 12:21:09

What happens when you deploy Win10 devices with AutoPilot, auto-register them in a different MDM(like MobileIron) and then remove the P1/Intune license for the user? Does it have a negative effect on the use of the device? Can this be done to save costs for company's who want Autopilot but do not want to use Intune as MDM?

  • Already asked in #microsoft_intune but there are 48users there, 192users here
DirkC (dcarey@vmware.com)
2019-05-09 14:36:46

*Thread Reply:* When you do autopilot or OOBE, your user account on the Windows machine is a Microsoft account. I tested it a year ago and the computer still functioned but you pose the risk of future issues with the user account potentially throwing up an error. It would be great to hear an official response from Microsoft. I have found that the doc team can be pretty receptive if you comment on one of the microsoft docs like: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-autopilot/windows-autopilot

docs.microsoft.com
Overview of Windows Autopilot
This topic goes over Windows Autopilot and how it helps setup OOBE Windows 10 devices.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-autopilot/windows-autopilot
Marc van der Kooy (marc.vanderkooy@gmail.com)
2019-05-09 15:18:25

*Thread Reply:* I can imagen that if the device needs a reset somehow the user won't be able to finish the OOBE itself. Device is still registered but as the user has no license the AutoPilot steps cannot be finished. (Same situation as when the user never had an AutoPilot license)

Marc van der Kooy (marc.vanderkooy@gmail.com)
2019-05-09 15:21:04

*Thread Reply:* I think that Microsoft isn't gonna tell if this works or not. Microsoft licenses are billed per use per month. This way you can buy licenses for 1-time use(1-month billed), enroll the device and remove license. Will save the company quite a few bucks per user per month which Microsoft isn't receiving.

Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)
2019-05-16 18:16:29

*Thread Reply:* For MAM only on Android just install Company Portal but don‚Äôt sign-in in the app. Company Portal is not required on iOS.

üëç JF Rigot
Amine (amine.ayad@gmail.com)
2019-05-16 18:20:11

*Thread Reply:* So you basically install it but only sign-in other MS MAM apps?

Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)
2019-05-16 18:22:01

*Thread Reply:* @Amine exactly. Company portal is required for the MAM functionality but when you sign-in it will enroll device to MDM as it is MDM agent as well.

Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)
2019-05-16 18:24:12

*Thread Reply:* See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/end-user-mam-apps-android

docs.microsoft.com
Android apps with app protection policies
This topic describes what to expect when your app is managed by app protection policies.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/end-user-mam-apps-android
Amine (amine.ayad@gmail.com)
2019-05-16 18:24:24

Amine (amine.ayad@gmail.com)
2019-05-16 18:38:56

*Thread Reply:* I've tested on my lab :

  1. Activated OneDrive and Word on iOS.
  2. App Protection Policies got applied.
  3. Launched the Company Portal to see if there's an App Catalog.
  4. Was asked if I wanted to use the account already used in the other apps. Said YES.
  5. Was directed to MDM enrollment.

Has anyone had the issue when deploying an email profile with username/password with Intune that an iOS device will not prompt for the password? Entering the password in the setting works, but there is no prompt when the account is pushed

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-05-23 13:02:40

*Thread Reply:* You did or didn‚Äôt supply a password in the config? Native mail app?

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-05-23 13:27:07

*Thread Reply:* No there is no option within an Intune email profile to provide a password.. you can choose username/authentication

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-05-23 13:40:49

*Thread Reply:* And yes, native

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-05-23 19:18:06

*Thread Reply:* And Exchange is where? Office365 Exchange Online? Or something else? When the device receives the config, mail will contact Exchange and the mail app will be challenged to provide basic or modern authentication. It seems the device does not, at first, try to connect to Exchange or Exchange does not challenge for credentials.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-05-24 18:11:26

*Thread Reply:* Your theory is right on the money. Tested the same today with a Exchange Online mailbox where the password prompt appears. We use Exchange On-Premise (2013), so it looks like there is an issue with Exchange On-Premise.

Jay Patel (jay991@gmail.com)
2019-05-27 06:36:21

*Thread Reply:* you can do this using Apple Configurator. 1st build the email profile with username and password > Export > Import into intune as custom configuration and deploy it to group

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-05-29 19:41:54

*Thread Reply:* Here is the official first response from MS - feedback? This is ludicrous! OAuth and HMA are mandatory for iOS native mail with Exchange On-Premise? I smell something.. [...] The email profile looks fine, except for the OAuth setting that needs to be enabled for iOS.

Also, you do need to make sure you have HMAhttps://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/exchange/2017/12/06/announcing-hybrid-modern-authentication-for-exchange-on-premises/ enabled, otherwise the email configuration profile deployed through Intune will not work. HMA will allow you to use AAD for authenticating users on Microsoft services, like email. [...]

You Had Me At EHLO...
Announcing Hybrid Modern Authentication for Exchange On-Premises
We‚Äôre very happy to announce support for Hybrid Modern Authentication (HMA) with the next set of cumulative updates (CU) for Exchange 2013 and Exchange 2016, that‚Äôs CU8 for Exchange Server 2016, and CU19 for Exchange Server 2013. What is HMA? HMA (not HAM, which Word keeps trying to correct it to for me) provides users...
Original URL: https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/exchange/2017/12/06/announcing-hybrid-modern-authentication-for-exchange-on-premises/
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-05-29 19:49:18

*Thread Reply:* That indeed will not help you solve your issue. It will change how exchange and the device authenticate, going from basic to modern Auth. Modern Auth is not a requirement for a password prompt.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-05-29 20:00:17

*Thread Reply:* Totally agree with you. üëç:skintone2: Also we have no ADFS, so modern auth would be hard! üòÇ

Anton I (antonn94@gmail.com)
2019-05-28 13:27:22

Justin Butts (justin.butts777@gmail.com)
2019-05-28 22:29:25

*Thread Reply:* @Tycho are you finding WS1 to have shortcomings for Mac Management? I can't imagine how moving to InTune would simplify management if you already have everything in WS1

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-05-28 22:49:21

*Thread Reply:* Shortcomings no, not as such. The simplification I intend isn't related to Intune or WS1, I just want to do less custom stuff on the Macs themselves because it bites us back when Apple change things üôÇ While I wish WS1 did things a bit differently (main gripe: Not being able to trigger actions based on custom attributes), it's a fine MDM overall for Mac. Especially since they introduced the Munki-based app management.

üëç Justin Butts
Justin Butts (justin.butts777@gmail.com)
2019-05-28 22:51:45

*Thread Reply:* Right on - always keen to get feedback on managing macs from anything but JAMF

Justin Butts (justin.butts777@gmail.com)
2019-05-28 22:52:06

*Thread Reply:* Have had good results with WS1 a few years ago but haven't touched mac management in a while

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-05-28 22:58:33

*Thread Reply:* It's a lot better now.. Before the managed app deployment it was quite hit & miss to deploy things and they had to be manually retriggered. Even something as simple as an interrupted network connection during download would make it fail. It's a lot more robust now. You should try it again if it's on your radar üôÇ

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-05-28 22:59:55

*Thread Reply:* I've looked at JAMF too but not in detail because we already had WS1

In case anyone is not aware, Microsoft has changed it‚Äôs sync protocol and it will come into effect when your tenant is upgraded to support it. We‚Äôve been using it since February and definitely noticed an improvement. More info here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/outlook-for-ios-and-android/outlook-for-ios-and-android

docs.microsoft.com
Outlook for iOS and Android in Exchange Online
Summary: This article contains architectural and security information for administrators about Outlook for iOS and Android.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/outlook-for-ios-and-android/outlook-for-ios-and-android

User Impact: Users are unable to check in their mobile devices.

Current status: We're working to restart affected systems in order to mitigate impact.

Scope of impact: Any users serviced through the affected infrastructure may be impacted.

Start time: Wednesday, June 19, 2019, at 8:25 AM UTC

Root cause: A portion of infrastructure that facilitates device check-in is not responding to requests.

Next update by: Wednesday, June 19, 2019, at 6:30 PM UTC

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:14:44

*Thread Reply:* StageNow is powered by MX

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:15:28

*Thread Reply:* so anything that you‚Äôd like to configure with StageNow settings, you wont be able to set with Intune under DO

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:15:42

*Thread Reply:* they are banking on the future of Android management and counting on OEMConfig for that purpose

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:15:46

*Thread Reply:*

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:15:58

*Thread Reply:* But OEMConfig isn‚Äôt a reality yet, its close, but not here

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:17:23

*Thread Reply:* Intune‚Äôs product team is aligning directly with Google‚Äôs product strategy for Android Enterprise, which you‚Äôd think would be nice, but that means that they don‚Äôt support any custom features with their DPC and only support whatever Google supports and Google has been pretty reactionary to the market with manufacturers like Zebra and Samsung building management capabilities long before google adopts them into AE.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:17:54

*Thread Reply:* Here is the MX documentation

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:18:25

*Thread Reply:* it is an extension to the base management apis provided by Google that enable you to do just about anything with a zebra device.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:18:47

*Thread Reply:* you‚Äôd be doing yourself a disservice trying to deploy the MC9300 on an EMM that doesn‚Äôt support MX with DO

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:18:48

2019-07-02 17:20:41

*Thread Reply:* you‚Äôll find that you‚Äôll end up setting most settings on the device using MX instead of using any native GUI configurations within the Intune console

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:21:02

*Thread Reply:* its basically a fancy asset manager that lets Zebra handle all of the device configurations via MX

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:21:45

*Thread Reply:* You won‚Äôt be able to directly administer lifeguard updates to the devices from Intune, you‚Äôll have to have intune send an MX profile and let the MX layer handle the file retrieval from a separate source like a ftp server

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-02 17:21:54

*Thread Reply:* you‚Äôll have to do the same thing for scanner configurations

2019-07-10 23:48:28

2019-07-11 00:57:27

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-07-11 00:59:03

NDTV Gadgets 360
Microsoft Teams Has Over 13 Million Daily Active Users
Microsoft Teams is claimed to have over 13 million daily active users and 19 million weekly active users.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:16:42

MX support is only under DA

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:16:53

Their DO support is awful

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:17:40

no file distribution capabilities so you can‚Äôt do basic things like Zebra devices like distributing scanner configurations to the DataWedge application which are datawedge.db files that get placed in a specific auto-importing directory. Intune can‚Äôt do that under DO

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:17:56

and under DA they rely on MX to actually do the work of retrieving and placing files

üëç Justin Butts, Tycho
Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:19:35

I implement Zebra Android devices constantly across hundreds of customer environments and I usually let them know they can effectively use DA and DO capable EMMS that support MX like AirWatch, SOTI, and 42Gears, so long as they aren‚Äôt considering Intune

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:21:01

Intune really does not hold up at all compared to the other offerings for Zebra support. Their DPC for DO is basically just the Google DPC so it only supports features that Googles adds natively to AE instead of offering any additional capabilities like direct APK installation, android file system interaction, scripting, etc.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 16:23:11

I‚Äôm meeting with their product management team today to discuss file distribution requirements. In working with them I‚Äôm hoping to improve their support long term, but for the time being I would not recommend using Intune with Zebra devices

2019-07-18 16:23:33

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2019-07-18 16:25:52

2019-07-18 17:10:27

2019-07-18 18:17:10

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 19:12:30

they‚Äôre starting to explore file manipulations so they can sync files to and from specific shared storage directories in android which will be key for the enterprise apps that use externalized configuration files that do not support managed configs

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2019-07-18 19:12:55

but they are still firmly committed to AMAPI for AE and are not going to build a custom DPC with added capabilities

2019-07-18 21:37:16

ZT will support work profile (BYOD) enrolments in Q. For now it's fully managed only.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-09-04 18:57:14

What is the main difference between SCEP and PFX certificate deployment with Intune? I get it that PFX doesn‚Äôt need an external published NDES so a quicker setup, but I am sure there are drawbacks!

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-09-04 20:47:11

*Thread Reply:* Here is a good read: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/certificates-configure

if possible I would opt for SCEP instead of PFX. See some pros and cons here: https://ronnydejong.com/2017/02/20/part-1-deploying-microsoft-intune-pfx-connector-in-an-enterprise-worldcommon-practices/

Another option would be to build a CA in Azure and use that one. Google for SCEPman: https://oliverkieselbach.com/2019/07/02/the-easy-way-to-deploy-device-certificates-with-intune/

Modern IT - Cloud - Workplace
} Oliver Kieselbach (https://oliverkieselbach.com/author/okieselbach/)
The easy way to deploy device certificates with¬†Intune
In this guide I will have a look at an easy way to deploy device certificates to modern cloud managed clients. Even without an Microsoft on-premises PKI your devices will get device certificates. These certificates can be used for Wi-Fi authentication for example. Normally if you want to deploy certificates to mobile devices you are looking at the Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP). To configure this you need to follow this guide Configure and use SCEP certificates with Intune which is fairly long and even takes about 30 min. to read. It involves various on-premises components like AD, CA, NDES Server, Microsoft Intune Certificate Connector and an Azure AD Application Proxy or WAP. A typical setup would look like this: You might have most of the components in your infrastructure but often I see customers without all of these or they want to get rid of the technical PKI which is used for just a few workloads like 802.1x certificates and move on to a cloud infrastructure. How do we achieve device certificate deployment the easy way? There is a solution called SCEPman | Intune SCEP-as-a-Service build by Gl&uuml;ck &amp; Kanja Consulting AG available in the Azure Marketplace. All it needs is an active Azure Subscription. A little background from the product description: Microsoft Intune allows third-party certificate authorities (CA) to issue and validate certificates using the Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP). SCEPman is a fully unattended Certificate Authority using Azure Key Vault for Microsoft Intune based device certificate deployment. SCEPman is a .net core C# based Azure Web App providing the SCEP and Intune API. It uses an Azure Key Vault based Root CA and certificate signing. No other component is involved, neither a database nor any other stateful storage except the Azure Key Vault. That said, SCEPman will not need any backup procedures. SCEPman is an Azure Web App with the following features: A SCEP interface that is compatible with the Intune SCEP open-source API in particularSCEPman signs machine authentication certificates with a CA key stored in Azure Key VaultSCEPman contains an OCSP responder to provide certificate validity in real-time. A certificate is valid if its corresponding AAD device exists and is enabledA simple post request to SCEPman service creates the CA certificate. However, if for whatever reason an alternative CA key material shall be used it is possible to replace this CA key and certificate with your own in Azure Key Vault. For example, if you want to use a Sub CA certificate signed by an existing internal Root CA. SCEPman issues machine authentication certificates that are compatible with Intune&rsquo;s internally used authentication certificates. They contain Intune&rsquo;s extensions determining the tenant and the machine. Additionally, the tenant ID and machine ID is stored in the certificate subject to allow common Radius servers like Cisco ISE, FreeRADIUS, RADIUS-as-a-Service and others to use these certificates for authentication. How does the exact workflow look like? As we already know it is a cloud service and uses an Azure Web App. Let&rsquo;s look at the detailed certificate request workflow: In Intune you create and assign a new SCEP certificate profile and target it to a user or device group. The device (Windows, iOS, Android, macOS) checks in and requests a certificate from SCEPman (the Azure Web App)SCEPman requests validation of the request from Intune by comparing a unique challenge (this prevents tampering)Intune validates the CSR and sends back a responseIf the challenge is verified successfully, SCEPman will request certificate signing from the Azure Key VaultSCEPman will receive the signed certificate SCEPman will issue the certificate to the deviceA more detailed technical certificate workflow can be found here Add partner certification authority in Intune using SCEP SCEPman will act as an OCSP responder and the detailed workflow looks like this: The device sends an OCSP request for the certificate to SCEPmanSCEPman checks if the device exists in Azure AD and is enabledSCEPman receives the results and if the AAD device is not available or disabled the OCSP response for the certificate is send as &ldquo;not valid&rdquo;For existing and enabled AAD devices SCEPman will verify the certificate with the Azure Key VaultThe result is send back to SCEPmanOn successful verification it will send an OCSP response as &ldquo;valid&rdquo;, otherwise as &ldquo;not valid&rdquo; How to deploy SCEPman now? Step 1: Azure AD App registration First, we need some preparations upfront to allow SCEPman to talk to the Azure AD. This is achieved by registering an App for SCEPman in Azure AD. Login to your Azure Portal with an Admin AccountNavigate to Azure Active DirectoryChoose App registrationsClick New registrationSet display name to SCEPmanSet supported account types to Accounts in this organizational directory onlyClick Register Next we need to copy and save the created Application (client) ID for the newly registered app SCEPman somewhere (e.g. notepad): Now we need to create a client secret Select the&nbsp;Certificates &amp; secrets&nbsp;bladeAdd a new client secret with&nbsp;New client secretDefine a Description and set expiration to&nbsp;NeverSave the generated secret somewhere because you are not able to look it up again The registered Azure AD app SCEPman now needs to have API permissions which we will grant now: Select the API permissions bladeClick Add a permission to grant required permissions Select IntuneChoose Application permissions as the permission typeClick scep_challenge_provider and confirm with Add permission Click Add a permission once againNow select Microsoft GraphChoose Application permissions as the permission type Expand Directory and check Directory.Read.All and confirm with Add permission Finally Click Grant admin consent for and confirm the displayed dialog with Yes The Azure AD app registration is finished now. Step 2: SCEPman Deployment &ndash; Azure Marketplace As already said SCEPman is an Azure Marketplace solution and can be easily deployed from there. Just search for SCEP and use the link for SCEPman: Click on the Create button Follow the Wizard and fill in the required fields for section Basics: Fill in the Azure AD app registration details for SCEPman (copied earlier): Wait for validation passed and click OK Click on Create and wait for the deployment Check if SCEPman is running by navigating to Azure AD &gt; App services &gt; scepman- and click on Browse to see the SCEPman website: If everything went well you should see the Vault, Intune and Graph as connected. As this is our first and single node in this deployment we can click on &ldquo;click here to start&rdquo; to create the Azure Key Vault RootCA certificate (this takes one or two minutes): Remember this can also be changed to a custom RootCA certificate (not described in this guide). If there is no need, you can create the new RootCA certificate now (SCEPman-Device-Root-CA-V1). If you plan to use the certificates for Wi-Fi authentication, your RADIUS must trust the public root certificate. The public root certificate can be easily downloaded from the SCEPman website by clicking on Get CACert: To ensure proper OCSP functionality, we need to specify an Application setting with the name AppConfig:BaseUrl set to the azurewebsite URL: AppConfig:BaseUrl To get continuous updates for SCEPman you can point a configuration variable to the maintained GitHub repository of SCEPman. During every restart the Azure Web App will do a check and a copy deployment if necessary. To configure this, go to SCEPman in Azure AD &gt; App services &gt; scepm‚Ä¶
Original URL: https://oliverkieselbach.com/2019/07/02/the-easy-way-to-deploy-device-certificates-with-intune/
üëç Tycho, MichaelM21
Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-09-04 20:52:23

*Thread Reply:* With SCEP the private key is generated on the device. With PFX it's generated on the server and then sent to the device: So it's less secure as ideally the key should never leave the device.

However, I have to say that SCEP is a PITA to set up, PFX is way simpler. Also, the certificate connector software from Intune has a very strong "beta quality" feel about it... Once you get started with it you'll see what I mean üòâ

If you use Intune however, many profiles can only be done with SCEP, including the WiFi Android Enterprise device owner mode profiles (COBO, COSU, COPE etc - and only from September onwards!), and WiFi for Mac and ~Windows~. Only Android for Work WiFi can be done with PFX. So you'll be looking at SCEP anyway if you want any of those.

üëç Mark Vonk
Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-09-04 20:54:40

*Thread Reply:* PS Mark I know I mainly said what's in your articles too üôÇ I didn't read them yet when I wrote that (thanks for linking!).

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-09-04 20:56:10

*Thread Reply:* Good summary! See my first link to check which profiles can use SCEP and/or PFX. Thanks Tycho

üëç Tycho
Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-09-04 22:32:52

*Thread Reply:* By the way, one thing to be aware of: the cert connector does not handle heavy load very well. If you assign thousands of devices in one go it gets overwhelmed, and the requests at the back of the queue time out and intune keeps adding more and more attempts for the same ones without cancelling the timed-out ones which makes the situation much worse.

Our PKI admin came running up to us asking why she was seeing tens of certificates being requested for the same users, and tens of thousands in total when we only had a thousand devices in the system. When we checked we couldn't even log in to the connector servers anymore because they were so overwhelmed the login prompt timed out.

We had to significantly beef up the cert connector server to reduce this happening. But still after a maintenance outage on the PKI they struggle for a while when catching up.

This is with the PFX one, we're still setting up SCEP/NDES in the test environment. But I assume it's the same there.

So try to assign them gradually if you can.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-09-05 14:47:24

*Thread Reply:* Great input with a lot of information! Thanks! I can‚Äôt find any info that Android Device Admin doesn‚Äòt support PFX for WiFi. Just can‚Äôt get it to run on these devices. iOS works.

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-09-05 19:45:50

*Thread Reply:* Yes I think Device Admin works. We don't use DA with Intune so I can't confirm. AFW (BYOD work profile) definitely works. Just the fully managed ones (device owner mode) need SCEP.

Make sure you assign all prerequisites (WiFi Profile, User Cert Profile and Root CA profile) to exactly the same group of users. This is critical, as we found after a long thread with support.

üëç MichaelM21
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)

Anton I (antonn94@gmail.com)
2019-09-24 10:12:25

https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/office/blogs/end-of-support-for-basic-authentication-access-to-exchange-online-apis-for-office-365-customers/

Microsoft 365 Developer Blog
End of support for Basic Authentication access to Exchange Online API‚Äôs for Office 365 customers - Microsoft 365 Developer Blog
Today, we are announcing that on October 13th, 2020 we will stop supporting and retire Basic Authentication for Exchange Active Sync (EAS), Post Office Protocol (POP), Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP), and Remote PowerShell (RPS) in Exchange Online. This means that new or existing applications using one or more of these API‚Äôs/protocols will not be able to use Basic Authentication when connecting to Office 365 mailboxes or endpoints and will need to update how they authenticate.
Original URL: https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/office/blogs/end-of-support-for-basic-authentication-access-to-exchange-online-apis-for-office-365-customers/

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2019-09-28 10:27:28

Intune MAM (no MDM) requires that the app (Tact) developers use the Intune SDK in their code. You can't glue MAM onto an app after the fact

2019-09-28 16:49:59

Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)

*Thread Reply:* Wrapping = app modification = app needs to be resigned after wrapping using your developer Apple ID.

System Admin (sagar080890@gmail.com)
2019-09-28 20:14:25

*Thread Reply:* My ask is anything required on Azure side

Tycho (tycho@schenkeveld.com)
2019-09-28 22:04:21

*Thread Reply:* You can do this but the experience is quite limited. Not all MAM features are supported and you will get an addition login prompt to log in to the wrapper.

I don't think anything is required on the Azure side no. They just show up like other MAM apps.

PS: I've only ever used the wrapper on iOS. We don't use MAM restrictions on Android because we leverage the work profile for that already.

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2019-09-29 16:33:33

*Thread Reply:* Wrapping only works with IPA files. Not apps from the Apple App Store

2019-11-06 07:01:14

Last week I enabled (enforced) MFA across the business via authenticator. 90% of folks enabled without a hitch, a few iOS users found themselves unable to sign in to outlook on iOS

This has persisted to now, either outlook says "cannot add account right now" or "oops something went wrong". Users can use outlook on Android and desktop no issue, and the error persists even with MFA disabled.

All other apps on iOS work fine, and MFA prompts correctly on and off the device.

No conditional access policies, app protection policies or management applied to these devices (yet). All that's been enforced so far is MFA.

They can sign into outlook on the affected devices with a different (test) account, but not via their own, the errors pop up.

I've tried putting them into Intune and pushing the various app protection/conditional access policies I have pending for stage 2, but the error persists whether enrolled or not.

No restrictions on mailbox/account, no exchange device rules that'd affect them signing in, accounts are identical to everyone else.

MS have been sat on the ticket for a few days with no progression. Has anyone seen similar?

Wannes De Boodt (wannes.de.boodt@proximus.com)
2019-11-11 11:54:01

@Wannes De Boodt has joined the channel

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-12 14:56:51

How are you deploying your OS specific configs - dynamic device groups or normal security groups? If we have one assigned security group for Android users and one group for iOS users, and users end up with an iPad and an Android phone, we push out iOS configs to Android devices and the other way around. If we use dynamic device groups, we cannot combine these groups with an AND operator to add a security group (to be more flexible with different use cases). This is a pain. How do you deploy stuff?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-11-12 15:02:23

*Thread Reply:* For us its a mixture of all of the above.

We etnd to assign policy by user, rather than device.

The base configurations are simply globally assigned to all devices. it doesn't matter if you assign the android policy to iOS devices as it will simply be ignored.

We also have specific exclusion groups for things like industrial devices where the default policy doesn't need passwords etc.

then we have assignments via dynamic user groups based on country or BU etc.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-11-12 15:02:59

*Thread Reply:* However this is the exact question that the "Policy Sets" has been rolled out for.

üëç MichaelM21
MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-12 15:04:49

*Thread Reply:* Ah ok. And you don‚Äòt see an Android policy within the iOS device details?

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-12 15:10:15

*Thread Reply:* Right, Policy Sets! Forgot about that! Thanks üôè

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-11-12 15:13:10

*Thread Reply:* Yes, but they are flagged as not applicable to that device.

2019-11-12 15:18:46

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 17:33:29

*Thread Reply:* Added an exclusion (dynamic device group for iOS devices) to the Android apps. Now within the iOS device details all Android apps still show up, but have the status excluded! Not sure if this makes any difference in the backend if it is ‚Äûnot applicable‚Äú or ‚Äûexcluded‚Äú, but from an admin perspective it is more clear. Let‚Äôs wait until adding Managed Google Play apps will be supported within the policy sets.

üëç:skin_tone_2: Simon Hardy-Bistagne
MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-12 17:15:38

Anyone using Checkpoint Capsule VPN on iOS with SCEP with Intune? It looks like when deploying Checkpoint Capsule via VPP (device license) the SCEP is not recognized by the app. Cert is on the device, but the app doesn‚Äôt show it. Using the app without VPP works!

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 20:17:13

The enrollment restrictions drive me nuts. I have created one for iOS only (iOS group) and one for Android Enterprise only (AE group). The problem with that logic: If a user has an Android phone and a iPad he is now member of both enrollment restrictions, where the one with the highest priority gets applied. So if iOS has the highest priority and the user enrolls is Android phone the user will not land in the Android enrollment restriction because iOS is higher. But since AE is blocked in that restriction you can‚Äôt enroll. So we had to enable all relevant platforms in one enrollment restriction. If a user has either an iOS device or an Android device but not both, this logic works. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è:skintone2:

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2019-11-13 20:19:40

*Thread Reply:* That's a pain in the ass, but not unique to Intune

üëç MichaelM21
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-13 20:22:16

*Thread Reply:* Why not create just one enrollment restriction for everyone? Or do you need different enrollment restrictions per OS?

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 20:22:17

*Thread Reply:* Ok.. well with MobileIron you can build really useful filter labels where you can pretty much avoid this scenario.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 20:24:27

*Thread Reply:* @Mark Vonk well yes thats what we will now! ü§£ the first idea was to separate it completely to have a more granular targeting for the future.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 20:26:25

*Thread Reply:* Also I think it was born because of Device Admin and Android Enterprise not being in the same enrollment restriction. Because for some Zebra devices we still need DA

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-13 20:28:03

*Thread Reply:* Ok. I never come across customers who need different enrollment restrictions per OS. I would not know a use case for that. Also with Mobileiron, you can set these kind of restrictions only globally (device registration settings on Core)

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-13 20:29:43

*Thread Reply:* Also, DA vs AE is not determined in the device restriction(s).

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 20:32:47

*Thread Reply:* That is news to me. If you have one enrollment restriction where both DA and AE is enabled, how would the device know which to apply?

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-13 20:47:29

*Thread Reply:* Not device restriction, enrollment restriction

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-11-13 21:57:45

*Thread Reply:* For us, the only restrictions are either platform (only certain groups can enrol windows, or hollow s for example,) or country (so blocking Chinese users from enrolling in Android Enterprise as it ain‚Äôt gunna work).

I can‚Äôt see any value breaking out restrictions into os specific rules. It‚Äôs all geared towards user based rules.

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2020-01-17 09:07:30

Is Microsoft moving away from basic authentication completly this year in OCT...? Any idea what will be impact on accessing emails via native email clients, iOS , Samsung and boxer.

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2020-01-17 09:10:18

We are planning to move away from basic authentication. So trying to understand the challenges on mobile device perspective.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-01-17 09:31:51

Yes they are: https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/office/blogs/end-of-support-for-basic-authentication-access-to-exchange-online-apis-for-office-365-customers/ All email clients support modern auth, at least iOS and Samsung mail. You might need to push a new Exchange configuration, with modern auth. authentication set.

Microsoft 365 Developer Blog
End of support for Basic Authentication access to Exchange Online API‚Äôs for Office 365 customers - Microsoft 365 Developer Blog
Today, we are announcing that on October 13th, 2020 we will stop supporting and retire Basic Authentication for Exchange Active Sync (EAS), Post Office Protocol (POP), Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP), and Remote PowerShell (RPS) in Exchange Online. This means that new or existing applications using one or more of these API‚Äôs/protocols will not be able to use Basic Authentication when connecting to Office 365 mailboxes or endpoints and will need to update how they authenticate.
Original URL: https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/office/blogs/end-of-support-for-basic-authentication-access-to-exchange-online-apis-for-office-365-customers/
Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2020-01-17 09:33:31

*Thread Reply:* I read this..I think only iOS 11+ and boxer supports modern Auth..need confirmation on Samsung native email app only..

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2020-01-17 09:33:58

*Thread Reply:* Did anyone migrated yet...

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2020-01-17 09:34:24

*Thread Reply:* We are using iOS native, Samsung native and boxer app..

Almar Diehl (almar.diehl@blaud.com)
2020-01-17 09:38:50

*Thread Reply:* Well, not completely. Online for Exchange Online.

Anton I (antonn94@gmail.com)
2020-01-21 09:56:23

*Thread Reply:* You'll need iOS 12+ in order to push the Exchange Profile with Oauth authentication enabled. From iOS 11, it's supported from and end user perspective (manually adding an account). You can also move to Azure Cert based Auth to get a "zero touch" experience. Or move to the Outlook app if that's interesting.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2020-02-24 10:31:54

*Thread Reply:* Detection rates are nothing better than reasonable, enough so that it makes more sense to continue paying for a dedicated solution while defender continues to utilise resource in the background (win). I‚Äôve had issues with it impacting device performance and the general lack of configuration does my head in.

On mobile the malware I suspect will be little more than an ever-updating list of baddies and nothing remotely innovative like that seen with lookout or wandera with their vast analysis/detection systems. On Android I doubt it‚Äôll be any better than Play Protect but again consume battery and resource to give the impression of protection. Hopefully their network scanning does a decent job.

Like intune orgs will see they probably have it and can leverage it for ‚Äúfree‚Äù, but like intune it‚Äôll pale in comparison to market leaders; the difference is where it‚Äôs ok getting by on poorer device management, it‚Äôs not ok adopting poorer security.

I‚Äôll wait to be proven wrong.

üëç Nico Hermeling, Norton

*Thread Reply:* Indeed one customer with the same issue. As soon as the device was restarted, the issue was temporarily gone. But soon reappeared again. Once the user was removed from MDM (Intune) the issue did not occur. No other users reported the same and eventually the user left the company.

TGR (tgr@twise.dk)
2020-05-15 09:21:19

First of all - Sorry for double-posting, but I‚Äôm not sure how many are active on the Citrix channel (at least no replies for 24 hours) and seeing that it‚Äôs a MS app-config, maybe this is a better channel to ask.

Trying to set up Outlook on iOS devices using a config xml, but account creation gets rejected on the devices. Has anyone got a working xml template?

I have it working for Android using the same parameters. the xml looks like this: <dict> <key>com.microsoft.outlook.EmailProfile.EmailAddress</key> <string>${user.mail}</string> <key>com.microsoft.outlook.EmailProfile.ServerAddress</key> <string>[https://URL_for_the_onsite_exchange_server_domain_name]/</string> <key>com.microsoft.outlook.EmailProfile.EmailUPN</key> <string>${user.userprincipalname}</string> <key>com.microsoft.outlook.EmailProfile.AccountType</key> <string>BasicAuth</string> <key>IntuneMAMAllowedAccountsOnly</key> <string>[Tried both Enabled and Disabled]</string> <key>IntuneMAMUPN</key> <string>${user.userprincipalname}</string> <key> com.microsoft.intune.mam.AllowedAccountUPNs </key> <string>${user.userprincipalname}</string> </dict>

TGR (tgr@twise.dk)
2020-05-28 12:58:43

@Woody it turned out to be a mix of nat rules on an internal network and the fact that the customer had just changed their exchange environment to hybrid, so the server could be set straight to https://outlook.office365.com/ instead of the on prem exchange server. The weird thing is that the on prem exchange server address still works for Android devices‚Ä¶

System Admin (sagar080890@gmail.com)
2020-06-15 17:17:45

*Thread Reply:* Well question is In user affinity, user will asked to put credentials and that's how it connect to Intune. But in user without affinity, how does the device connects to Intune and enroll? Think, you done all these in console and now you have to just enroll the device. How do you do it and what are the steps?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-15 17:32:12

*Thread Reply:* What is your question? What platform? Have you tried it yourself? Googled for it? Because it is actually pretty easy to find, or find out for yourself.

System Admin (sagar080890@gmail.com)
2020-06-15 17:36:36

*Thread Reply:* It's iOS platform question I already listed above ..tried to google didn't find answer

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-15 17:50:10

*Thread Reply:* For iOS you need DEP. Enroll without DEP asking for credentials and do not push the Company portal (in SAM).

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-15 17:50:16

*Thread Reply:* Devices that are configured with no user affinity do not support the Company Portal and should not have the app installed. The Company Portal is designed for users who have corporate credentials and require access to personalized corporate resources (like email). Devices that are enrolled with no user affinity aren't intended to have a dedicated user sign in. Kiosk, point of sale (POS), or shared-utility devices are typical use cases for devices that are enrolled with no user affinity.

System Admin (sagar080890@gmail.com)
2020-06-15 17:54:30

*Thread Reply:* Got you , any reference link for this please

Ajay Patel (ajay5675@msn.com)
2020-10-19 13:48:53

Hi All, it may not be a worldwide issue, however there is currently an ongoing issue with the Outlook app (in the UK anyway) - quick fix is to update the app if available and/or reset the account from within the app itself.

Title: Can't access mailboxes using the Outlook mobile app on Android devices User Impact: Some users may be unable to access their mailboxes using the Outlook mobile app on Android devices. More info: Impact is limited to users on Android devices, iOS devices are not affected. Additionally, users who can access their mailbox through the Outlook mobile app may experience timeouts. Users who have applied the latest app update containing the fix (v4.2039.3) will also need to remove and re-add their mailboxes to ensure that the fix has the intended effect. Current status: We‚Äôve completed validation for the long-term fix and expedited its deployment to the Google Play Store. Build 4.2039.3. is now available for manual and automatic update. The manual update is available for all users and we expect the automatic update to reach every user by October, 24, 2020.

Friends, I would much appreciate if anyone could share some experiance of moving from a "real" UEM (no offence) to MS Intune? What are the pros and cons (please skip the commercial stuff and the fact that it is a mess migrating alot of devices) I am currently running a quite big Workspace One UEM environment and now it is time to (again) evaluate and provide arguments for staying with WS1 or moving to Intune. I guess there might be other threads already handling similar questions, if so please point me in the right direction.

Best regards

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2020-11-24 14:02:56

*Thread Reply:* @Boe Has been going through a similar evaluation process as of late and probably has some good insights to share

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2020-11-24 14:03:47

*Thread Reply:* Also there is a #microsoft_endpointmanager channel that might serve you better for this question.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2020-11-24 14:07:47

*Thread Reply:* My perspective, which is strictly from the dedicated device space (Zebra, Honeywell), is that Intune falls incredibly short for that management use cases. Many of my end customers end up having to stay on Device Administrator with Intune rather than migrating to AEDO given that you can‚Äôt install APKs directly on Fully Managed devices, you have to go through Managed Play, and you can‚Äôt perform file management capabilities. There are workarounds using OEMConfig but that is a pretty convoluted process compared to how EMMs like SOTI or WS1 allow you to perform those sort of activities directly via the EMM rather than farming it out to Play. Again, this take is purely from the perspective of the dedicated device use case, but I would say that Intune is a non-starter in those scenarios. I in fact will often wince when I hear a new client say ‚ÄúOh we don‚Äôt need an MDM, we already have Intune‚Äù.

Niklas Jensl√∂v (niklas.jenslov@gmail.com)
2020-11-24 14:32:38

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for your replies! @Jay The reason to why I am doing some research is that we constantly are questioned why we use an "expensive" solution, not that I want to do it. I work for the City of Gothenburg (municipality) and we have all kinds of business cases, everything from students iPads (both 1-1 and shared ipads) We have healthcare workers, plummers, teachers, white collars, blue collars, personal devices, COSU devices, etc, etc. The only thing we do not have is support for any kind of BYOD solution. All devices are DEP/ADE or KME registered and Supervised or Work Managed. We provide all kinds of apps, mostly VPP-apps from ASM/ABM or Managed Google Play apps, but also quite a few internal apps that we handle via apk/ipa files. We also have a lit of webapps in form of WebClips. Per App VPN tunnel is frequently used and we use the WS1 Tunnel and UAG servers for that.

Niklas Jensl√∂v (niklas.jenslov@gmail.com)
2020-11-24 14:34:53

*Thread Reply:* One thing I often hear about Intune is that enrollment, installation of profiles and managed apps can take very long time. It do not happend instantly. Is there any truth in that argument?

Ajay Patel (ajay5675@msn.com)
2020-11-24 14:37:09

*Thread Reply:* yes this can be the case if using device groups over user groups. It's definitely nowhere near as quick as other MDM's. The enrolment process isnt as slick for sure. One thing that really bugs us compared to WS1 is having no "enrol on behalf of" if you have to stage a device before giving it to users

Boe (bkelley1982@gmail.com)
2020-11-24 15:03:09

*Thread Reply:* @Niklas Jensl√∂v yes time delay is a very really thing. I have been fighting the transition within my company and that has been one of many paint points I've pointed out. I recently had a call with my Boss and my Director to highlight this and showed them how I can remove a profile within WS1 in 30 secs when I suspect it to be the issue as part of my troubleshooting steps. I then demo'd in Intune how that same troubleshooting step can take any where from 7 mins (fastest I've seen personally) to 20 mins (the time it took on that actual call). After my director saw that he agreed to go back and look into what our licensing maintenance cost is and agreed if its reasonable to stay on WS1 awhile longer instead of jumping ship when we full license O365 next summer.

üëç Matt Dermody, Jay

While Intune from what I've seen in conjunction with SCCM can be a decent tool for managing Windows devices it falls short for all things mobility. I told my director point blank you gave me a company leased Lambo (WS1) and now you want me to trade it back in for Prius (Intune). Sure it can get the job done but who the hell wants to drive a Prius üòõ

üôå Woody
Duncan (duncan@govalux.com)
2021-01-19 20:35:15

Hello Microsoft Endpoint Manager / Intune admins; has anyone ever seen that an Android (work profile) device refuses to enroll when that user has more than 5 App Configuration Policies assigned? We are facing this issue on certain models, like Samsung SM-A515. We've got a case open with Microsoft and they told us to strip down to max 5 App Configs, which indeed makes it work again. But if we have 15 App Configs, that is not an enormous amount right? Microsoft says the following: Intune product group informed me that we are hitting an InterruptedException while doing policy updates. These are not generated directly by Company Portal application, CP does not interrupt it own threads. We suspect that this is coming from the OS due to the fact that the check-in process is taking a lot of time in the background. Java's best practices dictates that the thread should respect the caller (in this case OS) when it causes an interrupt, so we don't handle this situation explicitly. This situation is happening due to the large amount of deployed app configurations - all of which are setting permissions for those apps, calling android.app.admin.DevicePolicyManager.setPermissionGrantState for each. We don't know for sure if the OS has throttling restrictions on that call, PG will look into that, also if we can maybe batch all the permissions modifications into a single call to the OS API. For now, PG recommendation was to remove some of the policies for now.

Jason Bayton (jason@bayton.org)
2021-01-19 20:40:33

*Thread Reply:* Wow. I haven't seen this personally, but that's a weird one indeed.

Duncan (duncan@govalux.com)
2021-01-19 20:49:54

*Thread Reply:* And apparently it is not-so-easy as our support case started on 18-Nov-2020 already... @RJ did you maybe hear anything about this? In our organisation it is mainly SM-A515F devices that hit this (and we have a lot of those)

ZL (mobilepros@zolik.co.uk)
2021-01-19 23:25:49

*Thread Reply:* Ouch, good to know, sorry but it is one of those that you tell stories about.

Raul (rnadal@mobileiron.com)
2021-01-21 11:58:27

*Thread Reply:* Google training says that If this issue only happens to 1 OEM, (and perhaps on 1 model inside), you guys have to open a ticket with UEM Vendor (MS) and they have to open an internal vendor ticket with Samsung so they can fix it. That‚Äôs the official procedure for all UEM vendors.

If you can test over other UEM to compare, that will be helpful as well.

Raul (rnadal@mobileiron.com)
2021-01-21 11:59:17

*Thread Reply:* If it‚Äôs a general issue that happens to all UEM vendors, it‚Äôs the same procedure but UEM will open ticket with Google

Raul (rnadal@mobileiron.com)
2021-01-21 11:59:24

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs all

Not entirely ‚ÄúMobility‚Äù related, but is anyone here using AD Connect?

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-02-22 15:45:01

*Thread Reply:* Have SMB customer who‚Äôs performing hybrid-join/Intune enrollment but is experiencing lag in the sync process and it‚Äôs starting to drive them crazy.

Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)
2021-02-22 15:52:17

*Thread Reply:* Hard to say what could be wrong/bottleneck‚Ä¶ AD Connect use SQL database (Express by default) - There are 2 docs worth to check:

‚Ä¢ https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/how-to-connect-install-prerequisites ‚Ä¢ https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/plan-connect-performance-factors

docs.microsoft.com
Azure AD Connect: Prerequisites and hardware
This article describes the prerequisites and the hardware requirements for Azure AD Connect.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/how-to-connect-install-prerequisites
docs.microsoft.com
Factors influencing the performance of Azure AD Connect
This document explains the how various factors influence the Azure AD Connect provisioning engine. These factors will help organizations to plan their Azure AD Connect deployment to make sure it meets their sync requirements.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/plan-connect-performance-factors
Ladislav Blazek (ladislav@lblazek.cz)
2021-02-22 15:54:03

*Thread Reply:* The sync will grow exponentially based on the number of objects with references to other objects. Group memberships and nested groups have the main performance impact, because their members refer to user objects or other groups. These references must be found and referenced to actual objects in the MV to complete the sync cycle.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-02-22 15:54:05

*Thread Reply:* @Ladislav Blazek so their original approach was AD Connect running on a DC hosted in Azure. It was sluggish then.. so we built and migrated to an instance running on-premise (on a member server)

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-02-22 15:54:57

*Thread Reply:* So now that we eliminated a couple ‚Äúhops‚Äù and the fresh build is running on-prem.. seeing the same results.

Ajay Patel (ajay5675@msn.com)
2021-02-22 15:55:44

*Thread Reply:* might not always help but have you tried to force the sync via powershell using the delta sync command in the below documentation https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/itops-talk-blog/powershell-basics-how-to-force-azuread-connect-to-sync/ba-p/887043

TECHCOMMUNITY.MICROSOFT.COM
PowerShell Basics: How to Force AzureAD Connect to Sync
In every organization, the possibility of role changes or change of contact information can occur quite frequently. AzureAD Connect¬†is a great tool that allows administrators to make said updates either on-premises or in cloud and will sync all changes accordingly. It can take up to 30 minutes for A...
Original URL: https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/itops-talk-blog/powershell-basics-how-to-force-azuread-connect-to-sync/ba-p/887043
Ajay Patel (ajay5675@msn.com)
2021-02-22 15:56:42

*Thread Reply:* This is what we have done for some customers who use AD Connect. Just create it as a batch script and run it when needed

Azure AD Connect - Auto Sync on User Changes | Easy365Manager

For smaller environments it seems a good fit.

Philip Harrison (CWSI) (pharrison@cwsi.ie)
2021-05-20 19:19:58

Hey guys, has anybody tried to use Azure App Proxy to bring ActiveSync into an on-premise Exchange environment? Client is not ready to do Hybrid Modern Auth yet, but App Proxy gives a similar level of functionality (reverse proxy in the cloud, Conditional Access etc) without major changes to the Exchange setup. I'd guess it works fine if App Proxy is set to pass-through authentication, but I'm wondering if you could turn on AzureAD pre-authentication then do Kerberos Constrained Delegation from the App Proxy Connector to Exchange. It seems like all the bits are in-place for this to work (the Mail client on iOS supports modern auth, Exchange supports KCD etc) but there's nothing about it online so wondering if it is supported/functional or not. Cheers!

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 19:49:26

Hey gang! Here‚Äôs hoping everyone in the US had a great holiday weekend. Question: If I want to use traditional iOS SSO (as opposed to App Proxy due to weird browser/app behavior), can that be achieved via Tunnel VPN? I think the only downside is that the user is going to have to auth for their Kerberos ticket.. as opposed to using a cert to automate the process. Anyone gone down this path?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-01 20:38:57

Works like a charm. You can also do cert based Kerberos SSO with the DCs (KDCs) - This is fully supported on iOS

üëç Mark Vonk
ü™° Mark Vonk
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 20:41:16

@Peter Mohr So the cert that is included as part of the SSO Payload.. does that need to be obtained from an AD DS machine that the DCs would inherently trust?

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 20:41:58

Either that or add the issuing CA to the DCs list of trusted entities?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-01 20:42:15

spot on‚Ä¶ AND you need to enable Kerberos Auth certs (server side) on the DCs - Not there by default, but many orgs have it in place already

üëç Woody
Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-01 20:42:41

Theres a template in AD CS for Kerberos Domain Controllers

üëç Woody
Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-01 20:42:53

Enable that and deploy to all DCs

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 20:43:49

Nice. I‚Äôm ashamed to say it‚Äôs been 3-4 years since I had used the iOS SSO payload. Worked great last time I touched it, but once everything started going modern auth I just never looked back

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 20:46:21

Lastly.. the certificate that is specified in the SSO Payload.. traditionally it was SCEP via a connector. Is that still done using the MS Certificate Connector or is it now PKCS/Imported PKCS?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-01 20:51:51

MS Cert Connector is still they way to do this. You can still use the ‚Äúold‚Äù Kerberos with Modern Auth. Just add your local ADFS (or other iDP with Kerberos support) to your SSO profile and then you have cert based modern auth üôÇ

üëç Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 21:00:37

It appears the traditional connector + NDES (SCEP) is going to be the best way to request/issue certs from the trusted CA. Is there any scenario where the PFX Certificate Connector comes into play with any of what we‚Äôve discussed?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-01 21:01:01

Go with SCEP üôÇ

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-01 21:02:35

Yeah / I‚Äôve only had one customer ever use the PKCS, so just wanted to check

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-07 14:28:02

@Peter Mohr Do you know why the SSO App Extension in Intune includes a Kerberos facet? Is it just a more Microsoft centric implementation of the traditional Apple SSO payload?

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-07 14:29:01

For the specific need of said customer, I feel the Apple SSO payload will do the trick, but it is sort of confusing that there are 2 options

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-07 14:32:49
Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-07 15:01:52

Well ‚ÄúSingle sign-on‚Äù is the ‚Äúold‚Äù Apple Kerberos implementation. The ‚ÄúSingle sign-on app extension‚Äù is the new Apple Kerberos implementation‚Ä¶ You can swap between the two as needed. I suggest the extension as this also takes care of the site-aware thing so that users will get the closest domain controll and not a random one

üëç Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-07 15:09:10

Okay. I‚Äôve got them testing with the old (because tried/true), but can see the value in leveraging the features of the new. So if you want to run Kerberos for legacy stuff and also the Azure AD/Authenticator for modern.. do you just deploy the Single sign-on app extension twice?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2021-06-07 15:35:38

one for on-prem kerberos and one for Azure SSO. Yes, twice

üëç Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-06-07 16:14:24

Awesome. Thanks, @Peter Mohr as always!

2021-06-24 21:36:39

Anyone tinkered with Hypergate for Android via Intune? @Jason Bayton did a great write-up on it via MobileIron - Just basically want to confirm that the features/functionality are there to support it from an Intune perspective. https://bayton.org/docs/enterprise-mobility/mobileiron/setup-kerberos-authentication-on-mobileiron-core-for-android-enterprise/

Jason Bayton
Setup Kerberos Authentication on MobileIron Core for Android Enterprise
Introduction Kerberos authentication is a common method of providing Single Sign On with on-premise Microsoft Active Directory. This kind of authentication is also referred to as Integrated Windows Authentication (IWA) or SPNEGO. Android Enterprise lacks native Kerberos support, but with a 3rd party solution, in this case Hypergate, it's possible to ‚Ä¶
Original URL: https://bayton.org/docs/enterprise-mobility/mobileiron/setup-kerberos-authentication-on-mobileiron-core-for-android-enterprise/

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2021-07-23 17:21:24

Any idea, Can we have the option into Intune for iOS device to bifercate work and personal side like android work profile mode. Not looking for MAM-WE

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-07-23 17:51:50

*Thread Reply:* iOS/iPadOS offer Managed/Unmanaged apps and policies to allow/deny interaction between the two. There is no concept of profile or having the same executable launch in context of work or personal space. In terms of ‚Äúturning off work‚Äù like Android has, sadly there is not an option (though there should be!)

Todd Cole (toddcole13@hotmail.com)
2021-07-23 18:25:33

*Thread Reply:* What is the real goal? While UE does separate the enterprise data (unique encrypted volume) it is transparent to the user. You can also ‚Äúwipe‚Äù the enterprise volume without touching the personal data. As for the ITunes side of it I don‚Äôt know that the MDM is really the difference unless you are specifically layering the MS management tools that are built into MS apps and calling that UE (User Enrolled is a MDM management method that Apple devices can use with specific security controls)

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2021-07-23 18:08:31

In terms of ‚Äúpushing‚Äù a public app update to Shared iPad devices‚Ä¶ is there anything more that can be done in Intune (besides syncing VPP and forcing devices to check-in) to speed up the process?

Todd Cole (toddcole13@hotmail.com)
2021-07-23 18:26:54

Supervised devices can force app updates, not sure intune has that function(I am not an intune user) but from an MDM standpoint the device can force an app to update if it is managed.

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2022-06-07 17:16:00

Anyone integrated netskope with intune for mobile..can we enable without SCEP server

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2022-06-16 01:48:20

We are migrating mobile devices from airwatch to intune. When we have applied the MAM app protection policy for all MS apps then MAM policy is also getting applied to airwatch enrolled devices on installed MS apps..how we can stop this...is there app config we need to put for these ms apps..so that MAM policy wont get applied to airwatch enrolled devices on the apps. And its only get applied to intune enrolled devices with MDM and MAM only devices..

Sharkey (lukesharkey@gmail.com)
2022-06-16 01:52:03

*Thread Reply:* MSFT doesn't have a way to telling it is managed by another mdm. It can get compliance states from the mdm. But not managed state. So the mam policies will apply regardless. I've been through this same path and was disappointed. I created the integration from ws1 to intune and it was a waste.

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2022-06-16 11:05:46

*Thread Reply:* On the first page ‚ÄúApps‚Äù in your App Protection Policy you select if this applies to ‚Äúmanaged‚Äù or ‚Äúun-managed‚Äù or all devices types. Select only ‚Äúmanaged‚Äù and your AirWatch enrolled devices will NOT be affected by the new MAM policy

üëç Damian
Todd Cole (toddcole13@hotmail.com)
2022-06-24 18:26:22

*Thread Reply:* @Peter Mohr Are you sure? I would think they would still be managed (state reported by the OS) regardless of if AW vs M$ did it.

Todd Cole (toddcole13@hotmail.com)
2022-06-24 18:26:57

*Thread Reply:* From an app perspective it is managed when installed via MDM.

Sharkey (lukesharkey@gmail.com)
2022-06-24 18:37:54

*Thread Reply:* The MSFT apps need specific flags deployed as app configs to be recognized as managed by the app. The apps are not allowed to look outside themselves and check managed status. So you deploy them with a managed config and the app recognizes the values deployed and gathers that the app is managed because you can't deploy an app config without being managed.

Nico Hermeling (nico.hermeling@outlook.com)
2022-06-27 15:55:33

*Thread Reply:* Additionally - if you set APP to "managed devices", you need to set "IntuneMAMUPN" via App Config Policy (that is what Sharkey mentioned above).

üëç Sharkey
Sharkey (lukesharkey@gmail.com)
2022-06-27 15:56:31

*Thread Reply:* Exactly! Thx for the detail :the_horns:

Rajesh Kumar (rajes20@gmail.com)
2022-06-16 01:48:36

Any idea would be much appreciated..

2022-08-01 17:17:47

*Thread Reply:* If you follow the guide bellow it's okay, but troubleshooting is killing you :D

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/certificates-scep-configure

docs.microsoft.com
Configure infrastructure to support SCEP certificate profiles with Microsoft Intune
To use Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP) with Microsoft Intune, configure your on-premises AD domain, create a certification authority, and set up the NDES server to support use of the Certificate Connector.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/certificates-scep-configure

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2023-02-04 08:37:48

*Thread Reply:* Same.. Google is your friend:

Start here: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/certificates-configure

Decide if you need/want SCEP or PKCS. Build from there and follow the links.

This one has all the links needed to build the infra: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/certificates-scep-configure

learn.microsoft.com
Learn about the types of certificate that are supported by Microsoft Intune
Learn about Microsoft Intune's support for Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP), Public Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS) certificates.
Original URL: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/certificates-configure
learn.microsoft.com
Configure infrastructure to support SCEP certificate profiles with Microsoft Intune
To use Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol (SCEP) with Microsoft Intune, configure your on-premises AD domain, create a certification authority, and set up the NDES server to support use of the Certificate Connector.
Original URL: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/certificates-scep-configure

jafullersr (jafuller@starbucks.com)
2023-08-07 17:30:44

There is something called a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) that is issued to a Windows device upon successful login. The flow shows the process going all the way back to the IdP using ws-trust. Are you all using this? What about environments where ws-trust is depricated? https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/devices/concept-primary-refresh-token

learn.microsoft.com
Primary Refresh Token (PRT) and Azure Active Directory - Microsoft Entra
What is the role of and how do we manage the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) in Azure AD?
Original URL: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/devices/concept-primary-refresh-token

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2024-01-25 16:20:41

*Thread Reply:* First off, Intune sucks and I‚Äôm never surprised to here the constant list of shortcomings. It pains me that so many end customers fall into the trappings of Intune without fully understanding just how limited it is, at least relative to the fully managed device space.

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2024-01-25 16:20:58

*Thread Reply:* Second, this might not just be an Intune issue, as there is apparently a known issue with A13 that matches your description:

Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2024-01-25 16:20:59

*Thread Reply:* https://mobilxperts.slack.com/archives/C1V8JC31T/p1705947446411479?thread_ts=1705945707.533199&cid=C1V8JC31T

} Jason Bayton (https://mobilxperts.slack.com/team/U6J17V03E)
<p>I‚Äôm checking where they are with progress, but as workarounds go that‚Äôs likely to be the best path forward until it‚Äôs patched. Flagging apps as protected isn‚Äôt a simple go-around</p>
Original URL: https://mobilxperts.slack.com/archives/C1V8JC31T/p1705947446411479?thread_ts=1705945707.533199&amp;cid=C1V8JC31T
Thread in Slack Conversation
Matt Dermody (jmdermody@gmail.com)
2024-01-25 16:21:46

*Thread Reply:* This would however still be an issue with MDMs like Intune that only support Managed Play for app distribution. To your point, custom DPC based EMMs like WS1 will have more power over app installation and uninstallation and version control in general

Jay (vita@akut-hr.de)
2024-01-29 06:59:03

*Thread Reply:* In case you‚Äôre trying to remove apps on iOS devices keep in mind that you can only remove apps from supervised devices or devices that have installed the app through Company Portal. Everything else (BYOD) will ignore the command.

2024-02-06 07:16:33

*Thread Reply:* You can't set default browser with MDM on iPhones and iPads... For Android (Work Profile) you can push only Chrome app and then it becomes default. Or push only Edge and then this becomes default

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2024-02-06 19:34:22

*Thread Reply:* Deploy and configure the Citrix workspace app? https://docs.citrix.com/en-us/citrix-workspace-app-for-android/mdm.html

docs.citrix.com
Configure Citrix Workspace app using Unified Endpoint Management solutions
Citrix Workspace app for Android now supports remote configuration of your Workspace Store URL using unified endpoint management solutions. As an administrator, you can manage store URLs remotely using the AppConfig-based key-value pairs using unified endpoint management solutions.
Original URL: https://docs.citrix.com/en-us/citrix-workspace-app-for-android/mdm.html

docs.citrix.com
Configure Workspace app using Unified Endpoint Management solutions
Citrix Workspace app for iOS supports admin configuration of the Workspace app using AppConfig-based key-value pairs using Unified Endpoint Management solutions.
Original URL: https://docs.citrix.com/en-us/citrix-workspace-app-for-ios/configure/configure-workspace-app.html
